content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
												Why I love Five Nights at Freddy’s 1 Now like many of you I was a skeptic for this game. I thought: Surely this game isn’t that scary. So I bought the first game.I click new game and was greeted with the following message from phone guy.“Hello? Heeeelloooo! Uhhh, I wanted to record a message for you to help you get settled in on your first night. Umm., I actually worked in that office before you. I’m...finishing up my last week now as a matter of fact so...I know it can be a little overwhelming, but i’m here to tell you: there’s nothing to worry about, uhh, you’ll do fine! So...let’s just focus on getting you through your first week. Ok?” I thought oh how nice. At least this guy’s friendly.	“uh...let’s see. First there’s an introductory greeting from the company i’m supposed to read. Eeh it’s kind of a legal thing, you know. ‘Welcome to Freddy Fazzbear’s Pizza: a magical place where kids and grown-ups alike, where fantasy and fun come to life. Fazzbear entertainment is not responsible for damage, property or person. Upon the discovery of the damage or death of the third, a missing person’s report will be filled within ninety days or as soon as property and premise have been thoroughly cleaned and bleached and the carpets have been replaced. Blah, blah, blah.”At this point it started to get ominous. I thought: “What do you MEAN death?!” “Now that might seem bad, I know, there’s really nothing to worry about. Uhh, the animatronic characters here do get a bit quirky at night, but do I blame them? No! If I were force to sing...those same stupid songs for twenty years and I never got a bath? I’d probably be a bit irritable at night too. So remember: these characters hold a special place in the heart of children. You need to show them a little respect. Right? Ok.” It was at this point I fell in love with the animatronics and I even felt bad for them.“So just be aware: the characters do tend to wander a bit. Uhh, they’re left with some kind of ‘free-roaming mode’ at night. Uhhh...something about their servos locking up if they get turned off for too long. Uhh...they used to wander during the day too, but then there was the bite of eighty seven. Yeah...i-it’s amazing that the human body can live without the frontal lobe, ya know?” At this point I got the chills. I froze with fear.  “Now concerning you’re safety: the only real risk to you as the night watchmen here, if any, is the fact that these characters...uhh, if they happen to see you after hours probably won’t recognize you as a person. They’ll-they’ll most likely see you as a metal endo-skeleton without its costume on.”This calmed me down a bit. I thought “Oh well that doesn’t sound too bad.” “Now, since that’s against the rules at Freddy Fazzbear’s Pizza, they’ll probably try to...forcefully stuff you inside a Freddy Fazzbear suit. Umm, now that wouldn’t be so bad if the suits themselves weren’t filled with crossbeams, wires, and animatronic devices, especially around the facial area, so you can imagine how having your head forced inside one of those could cause a bit of discomfort...and death. Uhh...the only parts of you that would likely see the light of day again would be your eyeballs and teeth would pop out the front of the mask. ...Yeah they don’t tell you these things when you sign up...”And with this the fear was back. “WHAT?!” I screamed.	“But hey! First day should be a breeze, I’ll chat with you tomorrow, uhh, check those cameras, and remember to close the doors only if absolutely necessary. Gotta conserve power. Alright. Goodnight.”And with this the gameplay started. One of the first things I noticed was that I can’t move. That was truly terrifying. At least in other horror games you can run away from the things trying to kill you.I checked the cameras as I was supposed to. Everything was fine until 3 am. That’s when it really got ominous. One was missing. So the guy wasn’t crazy after all. I wasn’t really paying attention to him, though I did listen so I was lost.I figured it out but at four a.m. I experienced my first jumpscare: Bonnie.He was the first one to kill me and because of that I fell in love with him.My second jumpscare was Freddy. Freddy was just meh for me. He was just a big teddy bear for me.Next was Foxy. Oh man Foxy. I froze when I heard him bag on the door, and when he screamed bloody murder at me, I jumped back what felt like teen feet.I never did get Chica or Golden Freddy though.

Bake for 1 hour to 1 hour 10 minutes (check at 50 minutes) at 350°F (175°C), or until a tester inserted into the center comes out clean.Remove from oven and cool completely on a rack. content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												Hello, fleshling. You will love this game, or hate it. But that depends on your subjective and partial view of it. FN@F was developed by Scott Cawthon using Clickteam Fusion 2.5 as engine. The controls are fairly simple, you only use your Left Mouse Button and there are only 5 interactive objects (well, 6, but that last one is a small Easter Egg played for laughs). You can't move from your position, and instead only look on your left or on your right. The basic mechanics are fairly simple too: your goal is to survive from 12AM to 6AM each night, avoiding being caught by the suspiciously free-roaming Animatronics. Easy? Well, yes, the first night is easy; after that, the difficulty increases exponentially each night, introducing new enemies and improving their AI, even actively adapting to your survival tactics. And of course, it's not only a matter of using the correct control at the right time: it's a matter of using them with moderation. Yes, because all you do requires power, and your power supply is limited. Very limited. You don't want a blackout occurring on the job.This is Creepypasta material: NO SPOILERS, but the story is NOT a long one, but hell, when you realize it, good luck sleeping. It may require some maturity and sometimes patience to understand it. Some theories are still open.One last thing: the game is priced 4.99$. If you think it's too much, you must be in a desperate situation and you have all my sympathy. So, for your information, there actually is a DEMO on Moddb. And it's Free.However, considering you have internet for reading this, supposedly a home and PC, electricity, water and I hope for you food, then 4.99$ shouldn't be too much for you.

number of helpful: 16 of 22 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												Do you like horror games? Do you like GOOD horror games? Don't buy this.Okay, before I rant on about this, let me say this: This review is in no way affected by the fandom, and I do not rate a game by it's fandom. First off, the gameplay. The controls feel awkward. This takes place in a first person perspective, right? In order to turn your head, you have to move the cursor to the different side of the screen. Which makes for poor sensitivity. Don't bring the controls of console FPS games to the PC, there's a good reason why console FPS games suck: There's a deadzone.Also, the buttons, for the lights, are very awkward. In order to leave a light on, I'd expect to hold it, but no. You have to use it like a toggle. Sometimes, I find myself wasting power by turning and forgetting to click to turn off the light.Oh, and the laptop, don't get me started on the laptop. In order to pull it out, you have to hover the mouse over it. Sometimes, if I move over to the other door to check, I accidentally pull the laptop out, then I "die".The graphics look awful. Why is it that it looks like the background is just a wallpaper wrapping the inside of a tube. It looks distorted and disorienting. Also, even though the game plays in 1080p on my monitor, it looks like 480p. One of the worst things in here is the lack of settings or pause. If you can't see crap, then too bad, you're going to have to deal with the automatic gamma correction. Need to take a crap in the middle of a game? Pressing ESC will only shut the game down. Also, everyone says it's scary. I think the enemies look plain dumb. And if you happen to get screamed at by one of them, I don't get a heart attack, they just make me angry. It just plays the same old trope of something screaming at you from a poorly lit room. How original.I give it a 30%. It's terrible. Save your money and buy a better horror game, like System Shock 2, Doom 3, or I Have No Mouth And I Must Scream. Those games are actually scary, and if you surgically removed their spookiness, they would still be fun.By the way, I think the sequels are bullcrap too. They made so many of them in a short amount of time. Three games in seven months. And they all play similarly to each other. You know how people on the internet complain about Call of Duty having too many repetitive sequels released every year? Imagine if they done that for every 2.33 months. At least Call of Duty is somewhat fun compared to this garbage, by far I'd rather have CoD than FNAF. At least CoD has a redeeming factor for being a game: Gameplay. FNAF has neither of the two redeeming factors: Gameplay or story.

												I grew up playing horror games on my original xbox. So being a high schooler and playing the Silent games with surround sound and all the lights off at night was the ideal horror experience. Well after school, once I moved out sadly there hasn't really been that experience since then. Slender was cool, kept me on edge, but the it felt kind of linear. Mr No Face hides in between trees and jumpscares you. But this game feel so much more intense and even stressfull haha. The sheer amount of paranoia I feel as I glance back and forth countless times at the camera screen and back to the door to my left flicking the light on, then slowly inching towards the door to my right to do the same. All while Freddy stares at me from out of view..Aside my rambling, great game if you're looking for an intriguing backstory and a completely new genre of horror video games

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 14
												To start things off, this isn't the scariest game in the world. That isn't to say it doesn't jump me everytime I see someone out the door (somehow this happens even when I'm expecting it), but this game has a mild humorous feel to it in my opinion. They're lots of minor things that come together, and in my opinion kind of give a somewhat relaxed feel to the game (when nobody's out the door). These details are little things like how casually the person giving instructions speaks, your hilariously low pay, or clicking on Freddy's nose on the poster.That doesn't mean it fails as a horror game, though. The atmosphere on the loading screen creeped me out the first time I played, and the almost silent atmosphere in the guard room was pretty well done. As mentioned before, it always jumps me when somebody's out the door, even when the game is near mute and I'm expecting it.Overall, this game can be considered a jack of all trades but a master of none. You can get a chuckle out of it if you're in a less scared or panicked mindset, or this game can increase your heartrate by 50 if you let it. Simultaneously, you won't be laughing the whole time (A good thing if you want a horror game) nor will you get a heart attack (A good thing if that horror game wants a positive reputation).This is just my opinion, though. The experience could be very different for different people.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												Five Nights at Freddy's is a point-and-click, horror survival game created by Scott Cawthon. The game centers on a fictional pizza restaurant called "Freddy Fazbear's Pizza", where the player must act as a night security guard, defending themselves from the malfunctioning animatronic characters by tracking their movement through the facility using security cameras.The player must survive their shift, lasting from midnight to 6:00 a.m. without being attacked by one of the animatronics roaming the facility. The player, who sits in an office and is unable to move, is given access to a network of security cameras throughout the facility to track the movement of the animatronics. Four of the five characters have distinct movement patterns while the fifth, "Golden Freddy", only appears when certain actions are taken, however, most of the characters' movements take place off-screen. The player cannot leave the guard room, but can close the doors to defend themselves, and briefly turn on lights in the hallways to check for animatronics.Use of these actions consume the player's limited electrical power; if the power runs out, the cameras become inoperable, the doors open, and the lights go out, leaving the player with no defense against an attack. FNAF is actually a fantastic game. Even if the animatronics aren’t scary, the lore behind the series is the most talked about, most researched, and perhaps the biggest lore of any game ever. Heck, it’s the only thing that keeps Game Theory running! (No offence to MatPat. You are one my favorite Youtubers)If you have never played FNAF, you really should. Even if you don’t enjoy the games, the lore behind the whole thing, is something worth checking out. 10/10    Three sequels have been released: Five Nights at Freddy's 2 Five Nights at Freddy's 3 Five Nights at Freddy's 4 and soon,Five Nights at Freddy’s 5 : Sister Location

content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												☠Five Nights at Freddy's☠         9/12/2015♥Five Nights at Freddy's is a simple horror game where you take up night shifts as a security guard for Freddy's resturant, strange and frightening things being to happen when the animatronics seem to develop a mind of their own after 12AM. You have a limited amount of power and thus, very limited visibility while you struggle to decide if you want to keep the cameras/lights on or the doors kept sealed.First of all, I am really glad that I took the time to play Five Nights at Freddy's, even though it's not the type of game or genre I would normally go for, it turned out to be a lot of fun and actually pretty scary, even though you know what's coming after a couple of play-throughs, the game still has an ability to keep you on the edge of your seat.For a game with a simple premise and simple controls (monitor the cameras, click the doors or lights when needed), the game is immensely terrifying. There's no background music, save for occasional moments where the Toreador March plays (which, trust me, is not a good thing), leaving players to deal only with the background noises: the hum of the desk fan, the buzz of the florescent lights, the clattering in the kitchen, the footsteps down a dark hall, the dum-dee-dum of the characters... the silence, truly, is disturbing. Combine the simple controls, the nerve-wracking environment, and the lack of music, and within moments (and it's actually happening to me just recalling it) your palms are sweaty, your heart races, and every noise causes a panicked twitch.It's too bad that the franchise is way too over hyped, but it's still a good game!♥

number of helpful: 13 of 18 people (72%) found this review helpful11 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 17
												Five Nights at Freddy's is the hit new Indie jumpscare simulator game developed by Wisdom Tree for the Sega CD using click and play. In this game, you take control of some loser whose only job he can even get is being security guard at a children's baby play place. Now because this is a spooky Halloween scary game, it's got all the things you expect to make you wet your diaper if you're a big little baby idiot.It's got all the creepy music, and sometimes you see someone looking at you over there, and... Oh look out suddenly he jumped out in front of your face you weren't even gonna think you would've saw that right then! But you did, and now you're probably scared.What really ties together Freaky Friday is its innovative revolutionary gameplay system. It really maximizes the horror that  those blender Chuck-E-Cheese mascots have to offer.To play Five Freddy's, you click cameras and sometimes maybe close a door. You do this for convenient 10 minute bursts, designed with the big name Let's-Players in mind. Now some of you might be asking "But ROCKCOCK64, is that all there is to Five Nights at Freddy's?" And to you I would say... Yes. Yeah, that's it.Now it may sound really easy, but there's actually a lot of depth and strategy behind the gameplay. Sometimes you have to close both of the doors!Graphically, this game is perfect. Now, while in most other games, this look, this ♥♥♥♥♥♥, ugly, pre-rendered garbage wouldn't really work. This game however is a horror game, so you get to be totally creeped out by the one pre-rendered room you're stuck in that has this weird pixelated cylinder filter applied to it. You get to be totally creeped out by that and then pay like, a dollar or two on the app store to put a little plushie on your desk.The scares are also REALLY effective. Especially when you run out of power or one of your doors is broken, so you already know the loud scream scary spook is coming. Jumpscares work best when I know about them ahead of time. Then I get to plan out my funny facecam reaction. Some people say that jumpscares are a cheap and effortless tactic to try and instill horror. And that's just insulting and dismissive of how brilliant of a game Five Night Freddy is. Cheap and effortless are the LAST two words I'd use to describe this game.Would a cheap and effortless game have a sequel almost entirely finished two months after the original release? No!Would a cheap and effortless game take advantage of free ad space on gross websites to extend its audience? No!Would a cheap and effortless game try to milk microtransactions off of cheats and cosmetics through a mobile version that was hastily slapped together? No.Overall gamers, Weekend at Bernie's has earned its spot as one of the most legendary horror games ever. A game about being scared as the guy dressed as Chuck-E-Cheese giving you a pizza belongs in the same league as a game about the scariest thing the Internet could think of: A very tall, well-dressed, white man.Any dumb idiot can play it, and it makes a loud scary noise here and there, what more could you even ask for?FINAL SCORE:3/10 GAMEPLAYS2/10 GRAPHICS2/10 SOUNDS10/10 HARDCORES4.25/10 OVERALLS (BEST SCARY GAME OF ALL TIME!!)

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												Well, this game is currently really hyped and I can see why. I've never played or saw a game like this, really did enjoy the game till the end and still enjoyning it. It still creeps me out, even though I find it funny to die here. The wait makes me nervous and let me look around and click the light button. When I see one of them approaching I am scared and try to click the door button to shut it fast down. When it doesn't work... Farewell cruel world. I gotta say Foxy is the least scariest creature here, he only looks from the door at you and screams unlike the other ones who are infront of you screaming. Still trying to figure out how to  how to beat the customized night at max difficult on all creatures. I think it is impossible to beat it on this difficulty, well atleast I died before it was 1 am always.Now the gameplay, it's easy to understand what and when you have to do and what you shouldn't do. Easiest creatures to avoid are Bonnie and Chica, since you see them infront of your door before getting killed. Last two obviously the difficult ones, Freddy and Foxy who can kill you without to stop at the doors. I heared there is a " Golden Freddy " which I never encountert. As I read, you can encounter him by watching the poster in the west corridor. It will be in your office and do nothing for seven seconds, then kills you and lets your game crash. Maybe it's a bug that it crashes or it is supposed to be like this, I don't know.All in all, Five Nights at Freddy's is great for people who likes / loves jumpscares. I would say it is a kind of Tower Defense game without attacking something. It is good designed and well made. But sadly, it is a short game, it lasts like one hour - two hours, if you die often it could be longer. I would've like a longer version of this, even though the " customize night " is there, didn't entertain me long enough. Either I made it too easy or too difficult, which made me replay the whole six nights. To be honest, I would still replay the six nights because I can't change any difficulty and the calls at the beginnings, I liked it. So what are you waiting for? Go try the Demo and if you liked it get the fullversion.Atmosphere: 10/10Design         : 9/10Jumpscares : 10/10Length         :  4/10Fun              : 8/10

												this game is one of the greatest games i have ever played.story:you are a security guard working the nightshift at a chuck-e-cheese-like place called freddy fazbear's pizza, with many anamatronic anamals.however,  they are left in a "free roam mode" at night.[ultra spoiler: now, this would'nt be so bad,  but if they see you between 12:00 am to 6:00 am, they won't recognise you as a human. they'll see a endoskeliton without a suit. ao, they stuff you into a suit. the suits are not made for human habitation. they have no air holes. see where i'm going here?7/10gameplay:there is a small amout of power each night. all defences use up power.you have three defences, and two weaknesses.defence 1: door lights.your door lights help you see the blind spot in your camras right outside your doors,to help you tell when to close them. NOT ALL ANAMATRONICS APPEAR IN YOUR DOOR LIGHTS.defence 2: camras.your camras help track the anamatronics in the pizzarea. they can sometimes stop working though, and they may trigger something or other.. they may trigger a certain  easter egg that kills you or foxy by watching him too much.defence 3: doors.your doors are the ONLY WAY to keep out the anamatronics. they can be shorted out if you wait too long though.weakness 1:the anamatronics cannot be killed. your only defences keep them out, not murder them.weakness 2: YOU CANNOT MOVE. you can only use your 3 defences.overall:9/10 one of the best games i have ever played.

number of helpful: 116 of 214 people (54%) found this review helpful17 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
												Here we have a game that started an enormous trend amongst the internet, with mostly children around twelve and up playing the game, and despite it's horror factor (which is somewhat meager), it has spread as a strong internet phoenomena, and even since it's release date of August, 2014, exactly a year before creating this review, it has been extended in to a four-game franchise.If I wasn't 100% honest with this review, I'd say that this game is the spawn of Satan, or something ludicrous, but that really isn't the case, while I admit that the general fanbase for the game is realtively annoying and most certainly an indicator that the game is overrated, even I have to say that from my meager, but still existent perosnal experience with this game, I found the jumpscares to be somewhat fulfilling, not hardly as much as I'd have hoped, but at least enough to encourage you to want to play the game with caution.In all honesty, I do not regard the game as a perfect game, not even close, I would put it on the same level as casual game, but it has made itself a well-earned reputation, and it was clear that the devotion put in to it was strong, for instance, the 3D models rendered to make it were made with good care, and it was ensured that all of the materials rendered made the game look as spooky or ominous as possible, this was very effective, even to the point where seeing the animatronics up-close gave some sort of fear factor, to me at least.One thing that seemed to be weak and light about the game were the jumpscares, the pitch and volume of the noises emitted when the jumpscares occur seemed to catch me off guard, and the animatronic models, while retaining a cartoonish style to some degree, had some kind of ominous appearance to them, but the way these elements were stitched together gave no core-shattering effect that put a constant fear in you, in most cases, you know exactly when the jumpscare is about to occur, making it even less terrifying than it could have been, not to mention the overall weakness of jumpscares' use repetitively.Overall, I wouldn't recommend this game, not because it's a bad game, but because it just doesn't fulfill it's purpose, and that is to be a "scary" game, there's a fine line between something being sometimes shocking, and something being scary, and while this game tries to be a strongly scary, it still doesn't 100% fulfill the reputation given to it by the public, this doesn't by any means mean not to buy it, that is your choice, maybe it is that I'm strong-hearted in comparison to others, I don't know, but it's not a game I would recommend in all honesty.Rating: 3 / 5 stars

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												The game itself is amazing, providing a very addictive environment that also will force the player to use the restroom one too many times. There are a few Easter Eggs, most funny, and one lethal. The objective of the game is to hold off for 5 mandatory nights, as well as two that are optional following the completion of the fifth night. This game was based off of a Maryland pizza parlor, called Freddy Fazbear's Pizza, carrying the motto, "Where food and entertainment come to life," straight from the restaurant itself. The restaurant was closed down in 1987 and is still being investigated because of an animatronic coming to life and biting into the frontal lobe of what used to be (but she is still alive) a very happy customer. For those that love a good scare but hate spending money on the movies, here is a very great alternative!

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												Viral hype aside, this game does a better job of fostering paronoia and an unsettling atmosphere than most games of it's type, Indy or otherwise. The ebbs and flow of the game work in direct synergy with the gameplay, which while it is limited in scope, the extra resource management coupled with it's frantic pacing ensure you won't have much time to think about it. The surreal scenario only enhances the game further, as the unfamiliarity and constant looming uncertainty drive home the point that YOU do not belong here, YOU are the trespasser in this territory.Somewhere down the line we'll all look back at this and laugh about the whole thing, but for now it is the high-water mark for the "BOO! Haunted House" Genre. Very sensibly priced.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
												Although a lot of people say this game is overrated, it really is a unique take on the horror genre, with simple controls blended with an incredibly creepy atmosphere. Combine with lore that would make the Human Centipede frightened, and you have a recipe for success.For those of you who don't know, Five Nights at Freddy's is a point-and-click horror game that takes place in a Chuck E. Cheese-style restaurant, where animatronics are the main attraction. The four main animatronics (Freddy Fazbear, Bonnie, Chica, and Foxy) were allowed to walk around freely during the day, until an incident known as "The Bite of '87" took place, in which a customer lost his/her frontal lobe, due to a bite by one of the animatronics. After that, the animatronics were restricted to being able to walk around at night. You, as the night security guard, must watch the animatronics using a camera system, closing your doors when they get too close. If they find you, they will assume that you are an endoskeleton without a suit on, and will try to stuff you in a suit, killing you in the process. The difficulty of the game is that you have limited power, and anything you do (turning on lights, checking cameras, closing doors) will use up some of that power. If you run out of power, Freddy will come out and kill you. I would also like to point out the game's difficulty (for me, at least) as I have never made it past the 4th night. This might be because of my tendency to shut off my computer whenever an animatronic is at my door.So that's it. If you couldn't tell already, I strongly reccomend this game to anyone, horror fanitics or casual gamers. The lore of the series alone is enough to keep me intrigued for a long time. Make sure to watch the Game Theorist videos, becaue they are amazing(Also, it says I only played 1.2 hours, but I usually play this game when I don't have internet. It should be about 4-5 hours.)

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												This is a good game.For 10 minutes.   When it first came out, it gathered a massive audience because of its fresh new take on the horror genre. With its new widened audience came the FNAF fanbase. I know I shouldn't judge a game based on the fanbase alone but I can't seem to get past the screaming 13 year old fanboys every time I get "jumpscared" by Bonnie. Speaking of which- the jumpscares in this game are wildly overused and pretty cheap. After a few of said jumpscares, there comes a point where you just stop and say, "Alright... Is this it?... Is this all I have to expect from this game?" And it truly is. Other than the survival aspect of this game (Which mainly consists of waiting to push a couple buttons) that's pretty much it. That's Five Nights at Freddy's. This game is overrated in my opinion.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												Realistically speaking? For how it's made, it's not a bad game. It's not scary, truthfully, but the suspense keeps you on edge. You expect it yet you don't expect it. It's not a bad game at all.-Would I recommend this game? Naturally, given the jumpscares, no. But with how the game is designed, both in mechanics and visuals, I'd say yes. The game is comprised of a series of GIFS, not animated models like what we're used to today, this is more akin to older games. Very well done for that fact alone.-I sound like a broken record, but it does a good job of keeping you on edge, trying to determine which of the animatronics will pop up and from where. Bonnie and Chica, of course are fixed on sides, Foxy can come from either side and Freddy pops up when least expected under some occasions.-Even for each night lasting nine minutes, the suspense makes it feel so much longer.And the atmosphere adds to this. Eery.My recommendation for the game, personally, is to add more background compared to the skimpy details observed on the walls. Storyline based details. News stories clipped to a bulletin board only take us so far.Hopefully there will be an expanded sequel.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												FNAF is a good horror game that can mess with your nightmares you had as a kid about animatronics, and it gives that feeling of paranoia because this game has things you don't usually expect. For all the negative reviews, I say you don't really have anything that says the game is bad, most of the time I see negative reviews that really say the game is frustrating and was not scary, now I don't really see a problem in that, but uh I really find it hard to believe you weren't scared. I see other things negative reviews say,  like it wasn't worth $5, some terrible immature joke bad interviews and like the such, and I hate how people say this game is a youtuber streamer trap, really? Why...ok, first of all, I have a youtube channel yet I uploaded FNAF but did I get popular? No! All I got were like 12 views. But uh, going back to the other things like this game isn't worth $5...dude...that's like...pocket change in the world right now and yet you're complaining this game is too expensive? HA what a joke. But going back to this game, I can say it truly made me scared and paranoid at the same time. This game is definitely worth your time and worth your money, the sequel deserves even better praise. Oh, and might I say this game was when Scott Cawthon (the creator) was very close on giving up onon the entire video game industry because the fact that critics for his other games said that his characters looked like scary animatronics.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												There are a lot of people who say that this game isn't scary, or at least isn't as scary as it's hyped up to be. That's fine. What makes something "scary" is subjective, after all. Even if you don't have a fear of animatronics or don't react much to jumpscares, the one thing that I think we can agree on is this: The tension in this game is very high.Managing only one resource--power--seems simple enough but the room for error dwindles as the difficulty increases each night. Even if you know each character's behavior and how to monitor them, the speed with which you have to address them ramps up and you're bound to make more mistakes. Meanwhile, the atmosphere is doing its best to unnerve you to a higher degree as you progress. The noises in the game aren't so bad on their own but the last thing you would ever want to hear while checking the cameras is footsteps in the hall or Freddy's laughter, regardless whether or not they indicate an actual threat.Throw in some hallucinations and Foxy channelling Usain Bolt and you're almost done with Night 3.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												Invite the Demons into your Computer with Five Night's At Freddy's, a unique, one-of-a-kind Horror Experience brought forth from the crazy/genius mind of developer Scott Cawthon. No movement, no fancy mechanics. Simple point-and-click horror at its best. These monsters take the form of your inner childhood fears and stalk the corridors of a derelict pizzeria, eager to, without heistation, force your weak human form into a walking Iron Maiden and kill you in the most horrific way imaginable. One second they're there, the next, gone. But, always watching you.Simple mechanics. Open a door, close a door. Turn on a light, turn it off again. Open camera view, close camera view. Five Nights (give or take a few, if you play long enough) alone with 4 (5 *wink*) murderous animatronics. The question falls to you. Are you ready, for when Freddy comes for you?

content:
Posted: April 13
												This here is the game that started it all.. Five Nights at Freddy's is by far one of the best video games I've ever played. I like Sonic, and I like Nintendo games, but something about this game and its sequels just really stands out among those others. Probably beacuse many of the big game franchises have studios that make them, and those studios put ridiculous mandates on them.*cough* *cough* SEGAGameplay is simple, but that dosen't mean you won't get tense. Freddy, Foxy, Bonnie, and Chica are all cool characters, but by far, FNAF 1's coolest and scariest character is Golden Freddy. In FNAF 1, GF is by far my fave :)Also, I wanted to mention, people talk about the 5 main characters, but what about Endoskeleton in parts and service?? (Dosen't Endoskeleton have a fan base?)In conclusion, Five Nights at Freddy's is BY FAR one the best games and franchises of the 2010's. Probably one of the best of the past 40 year history of video games. Scott, I LOVE what you do!! Thank you for listening to us fans and we wish you years of good luck!!!Five Nights at Freddy's: 10/10

												I remember this game being popular when I was 14. It was still summer, and everything was good. As soon as this game became popular, everything on the internet was flooded with conspiracy theories, fake phone numbers, and that one viral photo of that pizzeria in Colorado. I liked looking at that stuff. I even binge-watched Smike's videos. It wasn't until this year that I actually bought all five games and realized what I missed. And though I enjoyed Five Nights at Freddy's, I can't disagree with what people are saying this game needed:  Being able to move around  (sorry...) Less jumpscares More horror A fanbase with less autistic children and furriesI've also noticed some flaws with Scott Cawthon's perception of old pizzeria animatronics that make design holes in the game: In the game, the animatronics can walk around and need to keep walking or else their servos would lock up, but real life pizzeria animatronics couldn't walk around at all due to being bolted to the floor... In the game, the animatronics appear to be made entirely of metal, but real life pizzeria animatronics had fabric coverings and rubber masks In the game, you take the "night shift", but I'm not sure if animatronic-based pizzerias ever actually  had  you stay there to take care of the joint from 12am to 6amOverall, I do like this game. I do find it scary, mostly because of the uncanny presence of the animatronics and the creepy sounds coming from the cameras. But unfortunately, this game about entertainment robots designed for children, was ironically  ruined  by children.Oh, and yes, I'm autistic if you've been wondering all this time. Fight me if you want.

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												So, Five Nights at Freddy's 3 has officially been announced! Choo Choo, all aboard the hype train! Final destination: your worst nightmares!I already posted a review of FNaF 2, so you can go check that one out if you want. I figured I'd just talk about what could easily be my game of the year 2014 and the biggest indie horror sensation since Slender (though far more deserving in my opinion). So is Five Nights at Freddy's really that good, or is it an overrated piece of non-scary garbage after all is said and done? Eh, considering you already saw my recommendation, you probably know my answer in advance. Ah well, let's get to talking about it.On the surface, the story of FNaF is very simplistic. You play as Mike Schmidt, a nightshift security guard at a family restaurant called Freddy Fazbear's Pizzeria that's based on Chuck-e-cheese. The mascots Freddy Fazbear, Bonnie the bunny, Chica the chicken and Foxy the pirate fox are represented as animatronics, and though they appear innocent during the day, entertaining the children with songs and games, at night they roam around the restaurant and don't take kindly to any humans still around. Your goal is to survive five nights, from 12 PM to 6 AM (around 10 minutes in real time), avoiding getting your face rammed into an animatronic suit. Sounds fun, right?The gameplay is refreshingly simplistic. Instead of moving around with a flashlight like in most indie horror games, you are stuck inside the security office. You can use the security feed to monitor the mascots throughout the restaurant, check the doorlights and close the doors should one of the aggressors get a bit too close for comfort. This would be a lot easier if you didn't have a limited amount of energy to manage. Everything you do uses power; using the cameras, keeping the doors closed and turning on the lights. When the power runs out, the building goes into a black-out, and it won't take long until Freddy gets his chubby bear hands on you. You can't close the doors all willy-nilly, you gotta do it when you really have to.Balancing is of course very important in every game, and FNaF handles it well. Foxy and Freddy force you to use your cameras while Bonnie and Chica require you to check your doors. In short, if you only use your camera, Bonnie or Chica will kill you, and if you never check your cameras, Foxy or Freddy will eventually get you without warning. There's a fairly competent difficulty curve, where new animatronics become active across the first few nights, and become more aggressive during the later nights. Unfortunately, with some very simple tactics the main nights become kind of easy. Even on the bonus night 6 it's perfectly possible to prevent Freddy and Foxy from even moving at all simply by watching them frequently enough. Yes, my main complaint about the game is that it's perhaps a bit too easy. Then again, Custom Night 7 allows you to make it as difficult as you want it to, so you could say it's a moot point. I just wish the main nights were just a bit more challenging.Now let's clear up a misconception I frequently hear about this game."In Five Nights at Freddy's you're just waiting for a jumpscare to happen."This is a rediculous statement. That's like saying "Super Mario Bros is just waiting until you get hit by a Goomba".  Unlike a lot of horror games, Five Nights at Freddy's uses jumpscares as a sort of punishment for failing. A succesful night will have virtually no jumpscares. You could say that the sound that plays when an animatronic appears in the doorlight is kind of cheap and pointless (FNaF 2 removed this), but they're not THAT bad. I prefer a screamer as a way to accentuate failure over one of those fake jumpscares common in horror any day.FNaF isn't all about jumpscares either. It nails other horror aspects exceptionally well. From the eerie dark ambient music that plays subtely in the background to the pitter-patter of the mascots on the move all around you. Weird circus music plays from an unknown source, mysterious knocking on the walls and children's laughter echoes through the halls. This game is filled with brilliant atmospheric sound design, and I'm a sucker for good sound in video games. I found the sequel lacking in this regard. Paired with the ominous dark rooms of the restaurant, the parts room being the most unnerving, and you've got yourself a highly immersive horror game that seems so simplistic at first glance.The concept of having sentient animatronics as villains in a horror game is such genius I'm surprised it hadn't been done before. It plays off the irrational fear of mascots and animatronics a lot of people seemed to have when they were kids (and perhaps still do). I can't say I have the same sentiment for animatronics, since chuck-e-cheese is not a thing where I live, but I know mascots at theme parks unnerved me when I was young. I found Freddy, Bonnie, Chica and Foxy so fascinatingly terrifying from the moment I saw them, and they were the main reason why this game spoke to me, but Foxy sprung out to me. While the first three are designed to be creepy stalkers, Foxy is simply scary. With his sharp teeth and threatening demeanor, he evokes a more rational, primal fear, like you would fear a wild animal. Seeing him sprint down the hall towards you is comparable to being jumped by a rabid dog. His design and behaviour conveys it perfectly. He means you harm in more obvious way.I would say Five Nights at Freddy's is more than a game, it's a psychological test. How well do you handle stressful situations? Do you easily panic under pressure? Because the game totally punishes you if you do. When you start freaking out you make mistakes and lose track of what is really important. It feeds off your paranoia and kills you when you start losing it.Horror is extremely subjective, and not everyone will get scared by the same things. If it didn't scare you, that's a shame, but you can't deny that Scott Cawthon did a damn good job on this one, especially considering he did everything by himself. It's a game that has scared the pants off of thousands of people, reached cult status in mere days after its release, introduced characters that are already iconic, has a deep and dark storyline that sparked huge amounts of theories and has countless fans chomping at the bits to see more of Five Nights at Freddy's 3 in the near future. Oh, and it's fun to boot.Five Nights at Freddy's is THE new IP of 2014 that by far had the biggest impact on me and I can't wait to get some more of that goodness.I'm Ready 4 Freddy!

content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												I used to like FNaF too. Mostly for its storyline. When the franchise was still young and beautiful I really loved this game. It felt unique and its storyline was absolutely fantastic. But now I only see a horrible monstrosity which has been milked empty. First and maybe second FNaFs were made with love and passion, but the last ones were... crap. Syrupy fanservice to milk some money. And yes, nowadays I dislike the franchise as a whole, but there IS reasons why I don't like this first game in particular.I'm positive that almost all of the fanbase is there because of the storyline. I'm not saying the fanbase is horrible and it certainly isn't afflecting my opinion in any way. Anyway, the game itself is dull and short, almost not worth its price at all. I admit, I only liked this game for its story. I was amazed how dull it was in reality because in all the videos it looked awesome.And that's the main reason I pressed the red thumb under this box. DON'T BUY THIS GAME IF YOU HAVE WATCHED ANY WALKTROUGHS, IT'S NOT WORTH IT! At first the idea of anomatronics was interesting and in fact scary, but after three games and so much hype they became no scarierer than basic teddy bears. Jumpscares were scary, but now when you can expect them, they are not scary at all. Believe me, watching videos about this game is much more entertaining than playing it.Few GOOD things about gameplay features:+ Unique and interesting systems.+ It really can feel frightening+ Cameras are an excellent idea.And then there's these not so good things.- Short. Not worth it.- So overhyped.- Franchise has been milked dry.- No replay value at all.If you are one of those very few who found this game only recently and you've not yet watched anything about this, this game is ok. I don't like its gameplay, it's something that Greenlight usually gives birth to, nothing less, nothing more. It can feel frigtening when you play it for the first time, but after watching 100hrs video material about it and played it trough 100 times, it's not so interesting anymore.If you still like the storyline, nothing is in your way to theorize about it and attend discussion. This game can't give you any more information than let's plays do. In fact, it gives less. I strongly believe that this whole great story was born accidentally.

content:
Posted: February 10
												I'm going to give this game a 4.5/10.No, this review isn't going to all be bashing on FNAF fans. No, this review isn't going to be saying "The fnaf faendum is cancur xddd"Yes, this review is going to be constructive critism. Let's start off with cons:- The fandom.I'm not saying it's cancer. I'm just saying that at least 50% of the fandom ruined this game with fetish art, shipping, sexualising the animatronics, etc. I have absolutely  No problem with this, as i rarely see this kind of art anymore. - The jumpscares.The jumpscares aren't even scary anymore. It's just animatronics screaming at your face with wide eyes, nothing scary about that.If you're a fan of jumpscares, feel free to buy this game. If not; Don't waste your money.- The storyThe story is too cheesy.  Someone dressed up as purple freddy, grabbed a knife, lead 5 children into the backstage, and stabbed them and then the children possessed the animatronics and now they kill people. Sounds cheesy when you put it that way, huh?Now, the pros:- The suspense you getThe suspense you get, even at night 1.The phone call ends, bonnies gone, where's bonnie? At the door. He's gone, roams around, at the door, door is jammed, 6 AM. Thats pretty much it. I have no grudges against people who like FNAF/FNAF fans, i'm just voicing my opinion.

Posted: August 22, 2014
												This is a good indie horror game, it's not great as the replayability is little to none after day 6 unless you've grown a taste for screaming both angrily and in fear, the atmosphere is very disturbing as even though it takes place in a pizza parlor after hours (Which would be most any kid's dream if it weren't Freddy's place..) and the fact the animatronic animals will kill you while screaming and moving right in your face is definitely worth saying "jumpscares galore" as well as the fact you have a very limited amount of power to Check cameras for the animatrons, Close the doors before they get you, or Check the door lights to see if they're there or not, you need to survive 6 hours per night (About 3 - 5 minutes per hour, right around there) while the AI gets notably harder with each new night (Night 1 obviously is the easiest as most of them will idle except for two and night 5 or the bonus 6th night are the worst scarefactors as they will easily overrun you unless you've figured out this game's system of checking the cameras/doors/lights.) but besides the atmosphere and scares from the animatrons the game's mild, there's no real objective besides living and the story is non-existant unless you go out of your way to google it.This game gets a 7.5/10

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												Five Nights is the epitome of horror games. It is fear in gaming distilled to its purest form; an experience that forces you to give it your full attention and focus while it strips you of any sense of balance or safety. It is unnerving and upsetting to its core.What truly makes this remarkable is how simple the game is. There is really only one action: Close the Door button only and always when you think you're about to be attacked. Close too early, and you waste power. Close too late, and you are doomed.All the rest is window dressing to this, but what is there is so perfectly executed. I must emphasize that what I say is praise. The simplicity is to its benefit, providing you with absolutely nothing to distract you from your feelings of foreboding, dread, and terror.This is, in many ways, the perfect horror game.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												Five Nights at Freddy's is an indie horror game made by Scott Cawthon. You have to survive 5 nights at a Chuck E. Cheese-esque place called 'Freddy Fazbear's Pizza'. What do you have to survive? Animatronics, yes, animatronics. The four main animatronics are Freddy, Bonnie, Chica and Foxy who all have different attack patterns; different ways to get to YOU. Here are some things that Five Nights at Freddy's does well: Making the player feel challenged: Five Nights at Freddy's starts out very easy but then ramps up the difficulty, especially in the later nights. Making the player feel helpless: Now, it goes without saying that if you were stuck in a place with 4 killer robot furries, you'd feel pretty helpless. And sense you're in a tiny office just waiting for you to get stuffed into a suit, it amplifies it. Fear: Five Nights at Freddy's will obviously be scary, right? Yes, it is scary. If you fail to stay alive through a night, you will be killed by one of the robots in a... jumpscare... "A cheap jumpscare? Really?" you might ask. Yeah, the deaths are jumpscares, but it isn't the jumpscare that scares you, it's not knowing when it will happen. If the death is predictable, then it isn't as scary.As a final review for Five Nights at Freddy's, I give it a 9.9/10.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												This game is great. When people look at this at first they think it's scary, so they buy it. When they buy it, they wait for 2 in game nights and wait for something to happen. And before I actually start this is from my friend's perspective. Around half way through 2 AM the bunny leaves. He checks that he is in the supply closet. 												This game only seems scary when you play it. You can watch Youtubers play it or your friends and it just won't give you the same feeling as when you play. What's that feeling? A quickly escalating scense that somethings about to happen to you. And when it doens't happen right away then the pressure just builds. The pressure is probably what makes this game the best. number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 2
												The game was a huge hit in the Indie Horror category of games, getting 3rd place in the category for the 2014 Global game awards. Over hundreds of Youtubers have critiqued this game, and with the positive reviews in all stores sold I was intrigued in giving it a try.  The animations and graphics in the game is very limited since we have only the office and the security cameras to look at, but by no means were they dull. This left room to add nice effects, such as the statics in the cameras, blinking lights to even the honking nose of the Freddy Fazbear poster on the wall! Like any Horror game, it has its nerve-racking moments and FNAF seems to induce profuse amounts of it. Every waking moment in playing this game will leave you trembling until 6:00 AM, with the only calming remedy being the sound of the timer once it’s morning or when you hear the ‘phone guy’ speaking. But even the latter does not last long.I’ll leave my review at that, with no details on the animatronics (that may lead to potential spoilers). I enjoyed playing this game, despite the complaints about how simple and repetitive the goal is. Each and every stage we are introduced to new challenges, and (seemingly) longer nights. FNAF is a must-play for anyone who is engrossed in all aspects of a classic and/or simple horror game.

content:
Posted: February 20
												Honetly loved everything about this game!!  Its story gives great background information about the characters and various going-ons throughout the game, especially the "phone guy," along with the newspaper article as well.  I love the sound effects in the background that makes one just feel the suspense and when something may or may not be closer or at either door on either side of the room you're placed in.  There's probably only one thing, whether it's an actual part of the game or not, which would be some of the mechanics; they're a bit glitchy, mainly the door lights on either side of you.  They tend to stay on for either a brief moment or for quite awhile after being clicked the second time in order to turn them off.  Despite this factor, the game is absolutely astonishing as well as pretty freakin' scary!  It definitely gave me the creeps during my first go-around, but 'cause I'm just "too pro" at my gaming hobby, I'm totally over it now... except when Foxy jumpscares me though.  I swear, that just gets me every time!  I'd say on a scale of 1-10, this game gets a 9.5 out of me!  ~Shea

												Well you all knew this was coming so here it is, Five Night's at Freddy's, a point and click horror game made by Scott Cawthon has his final attempts to make a video game, but of course now it's Final Fantasy all over again. You play as the night guard at a family pizzarea called Freddy Fazbear's Pizza. Sounds simple enough... if it wasn't for the animatronics out to kill you. Your only advantages of defending yourself is using the sercurity camera to check on where the animatronics are, a light switch to see if anyone is coming to get you, and a door switch to close the doors, while dealing with a limited amount of power. It's a good game with a decent amount of challenge.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2016
												The basic premise of Five Nights at Freddy's demands the player spend the vast majority of the game inactive. The diminishing power supply - the resource used for protection - actually incentivizes sitting still and waiting. Not that there's much that can be done, electricity or no. There are two doors, a light for each door, and series of security cameras to check. There's not even an in-game menu, esc just closes the game entirely. But surprisingly, inactivity and the helplessness that develops from that lack of options, only strengthens the inevitable jump scare. While Five Nights at Freddy's is very clear about what it has to offer, it does bear repeating: this is not a game that lends itself to speculation or any sort of terror that would outlast the experience; anticipation and jump scares are all that can be found here.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												It's hard to find something to say about Five Nights at Freddy's that hasn't already been said. I'm a huge fan of horror and have played just about every horror game, watched every horror movie (even the cheesy ones) and read every online ghost story and creepypasta there is so obviously, I'm a bit more harsh when judging a piece of horror. I can't necessarily say Five Nights at Freddy's is "scary" as much as it is tense. VERY similar to Slender in that the game relies on the tension caused by the feeling of paranoia and the feeling of being hunted to get into the player's mind. The problem though is that this game's tension is built more so out of the fact that you don't want one of the animals jumping up and screaming at you loudly, not so much that you actually feel in danger like you would in Slender or games similar. Because of that and the fact that while you don't know EXACTLY when the jump scare will occur but get a good idea of when it's coming (animal is close to your room in the camera feed, clicking sound when trying to turn on light, etc.) leaves this game feeling more like a digital version of a jack in the box rather than a real, horror experience. All that being said, I still very much enjoy this game and (especially considering the price) would definitely recommend it to anyone interested in it. A good piece of horror? No. A good experience? Yes.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												It's hard to find something to say about Five Nights at Freddy's that hasn't already been said. I'm a huge fan of horror and have played just about every horror game, watched every horror movie (even the cheesy ones) and read every online ghost story and creepypasta there is so obviously, I'm a bit more harsh when judging a piece of horror. I can't necessarily say Five Nights at Freddy's is "scary" as much as it is tense. VERY similar to Slender in that the game relies on the tension caused by the feeling of paranoia and the feeling of being hunted to get into the player's mind. The problem though is that this game's tension is built more so out of the fact that you don't want one of the animals jumping up and screaming at you loudly, not so much that you actually feel in danger like you would in Slender or games similar. Because of that and the fact that while you don't know EXACTLY when the jump scare will occur but get a good idea of when it's coming (animal is close to your room in the camera feed, clicking sound when trying to turn on light, etc.) leaves this game feeling more like a digital version of a jack in the box rather than a real, horror experience. All that being said, I still very much enjoy this game and (especially considering the price) would definitely recommend it to anyone interested in it. A good piece of horror? No. A good experience? Yes.

content:

												A spectacularly-frightening game that is honestly worth every penny. What you need to do in this game is to survive 5 nights as a security guard in Freddy Fazzbear's Pizzariea. This requires that you utelize cameras, lights, and the two doors that lead into your room, to monitor and protect yourself from the deadly animatronic mascots that wander around at night.But why is this scary? Here is why:-You can't move from your security room. All you can do is wait for them to come to you!- Everything you can do drains power. So you have to balance security vs. sustianing the power.- The monsters will look at you and watch your every move throughout the camera waching, and when they show up at your freakin doorstep.And much, much more. I don't really want to give too much away about this game because of how terrifying it is when you know less about it.Simply put; BUY THIS GAME! Is your body ready for Freddy?

content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												This game is mighty scary! My bowels nearly bursted as I played the first night! Bun Bun the Spook snuck up on me as I work to say "hello! Would you like some pizza and some soda?" I rejected his greeting and decided to shut the door on his face. After playing the 'Interrogation Song' on my Iphone multiple times, Duckster heard the beautiful music and decided to join the party and dance. Her dancing was so terrible, that I accidentaly threw up and closed the door!!!1!!! Of course they started crying like babies behind the doors and ran off to tell Freddy the Bear about my rude actions. Freddy didn't care, but simply stared at the camera menacingly, an obvious way to tell me to sit in the corner. Being the rebel I am, I didn't sit in the corner. The duck later did her business the entire night, possibly touching herself in the kitchen. She was making awful grunting and moaning noises in there, sending chills up my spine. I let her do her business until my shift was over. Although Bun Bun was still behind the door, I made it out alive. Being desperate for the $4 an hour, I came back to the attraction unarmed the next day.Moral of story, I recommend this game to brave souls like Mermaid Man.P.S I never got my cash for the first night.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												Night Trap with furries. While the concept might sound kind of lame and hokey, in execution it's a damned fine minimalist horror game.You're an underpaid security guard for a kid's entertainment center, and during the night shift, the animatronic animals come to life and wander the halls. You must check your camera feed constantly to see where they're ambling about, power the lights outside your office to see if any of them are at the door, and slam the doors in their face before they horrifically mutilate you by stuffing you into a spare suit. You have a limited amount of dwindling power to see you through the night, and checking the video feed, powering the door lights, and shutting the doors all drain your reserves.The plot and the gameplay don't mesh too well, but this isn't a game you play for the plot. It's a game you play to experience that special sort of tension that comes from the fear of the unknown. You'll scramble to check your feeds as you hear kitsch music and shuffling steps echoing through the hallways, your paranoia will claw at you as you leave the video feed and the lights off to conserve power, you'll panic when the animals play peekaboo outside your door and come running down the halls looking for human blood.This game is cheap at $4.99. If you have any love for true horror, you'll at least give this game a chance.

												I recommened this game to anyone who likes horror and/or wants a challenge! This game was a brand new look/start to a different kind of horror that we're used to, you know, remember when all horror games was just Slenderman clones? This game, to some, isn't all that scary, but you got to admit, it's very tense!! It keeps you on the edge of your seat! Not to mention it's amazing backstory!! 												Amazingly fun horror, if you like to jump out of your chair.This game is pretty basic and incredibly fun, there's not much to say about this game except you'll spend a fair bit of time trying to complete it and you won't give up because your bored..The game can be incredibly difficult but is a great way to eat time up late at night.It shows that for a game to be good you don't need good graphics, this game is locked to 720p which is okay but there are no graphics options at all. number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												I've always held that the cheapest kind of "horror" games are ones that exclusively use “jumpy” horror as their vehicle for scares.  This is the reason games like Dead Space or Doom 3 aren't very scary--as usually the jumps are predictable and are startling, not *horrifying.* This is because there is no atmosphere or pacing which are requirements for a true horror game.  It’s also impossible to be truly horrified if you’re carrying enough weaponry to turn the installation you’re inside into ash.  So, why do I love FNAF, when it proudly boasts that it has tons of jump-scares?  It is because it also has the other ingredients for a true horror game:  Good atmosphere and sound engineering, a very scarce and crucial resource for survival, a feeling of helplessness and insignificance, and the fact that in addition to the many jump-scares, your imagination is what produces most of the feelings of dread and terror when playing this game.  This is what makes the game stand out as a true horror game like Silent Hill 2 or Amnesia, the game gives you the tools to interact with it, a plot with basic instructions,  and then sits back and lets you s*** your pants by yourself.  Buy it!  We need to encourage more innovation like this.Do NOT play if you have hypertension or heart trouble, or if you have a full bladder.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												Five Nights at Chuck E. Cheese's is what it suggests, you spend 5-6 nights there because you are a security guard. Sounds boring however Winnie the Pooh, Chuck, Bugs Bunny, Daffy Duck, and Tigger all come to life to play with you with a nice game of hide and seek, however their rules are different than common Hide and Seek. They run around, knowing where you are to "tag" you, however you get several cameras to spot them and doors to close to make it harder for them. You have a time limit and power, of course, but the reason they do this is because after 6 am, they have to go to their original spots until 12 am. While you are working there, your buddy, Christopher, calls you and drops several hints, so you need to listen to him. Best part of all, you get free pizza, drinks, games, you meet famous characters, and, to top it all off, you get paid just for having fun with those characters.Overall, this is a great, fun, casual game that you can just come home to start it up and forget all about your worries.12/10

content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												Need to make some extra cash?  Got your attention now?  Security guard needed  (no experience needed)!  All you have to do is watch over Freddy Fazbear's Pizza at night from......you know theifs and stuff.  You'll have access to 11 different cameras all around the establishment and secure metal doors if anything is to happen.....Like annoying people begging for loose change.  You will also have access to a light outside your door so you can.....see whats outside your door.  Oh whats that?  There shouldn't be anything outside your door at all.  Well anywho your shift starts at 12am and you'll be off at 6am.  The graveyard shift.  Nothing ever goes on during these hours anyway.  Its like FREE money.  Just watch some cameras, kick your feet up and close a few doors during your shift.  Oh did I mention you also have access to a telephone?  Sweet I know, and without further ado the pay.  You will recieve a solid grand total of $120 per week!  Now how does that sound?  Sign up now by clicking "add to cart" and start making that CA$H!  Don't waste another minute!

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												First off, this can be a really tense game, depending on how you play it and if you actually get scared from horror games (which I usually am not).  The one bad part I have encountered so far (after 3 nights in my first playthrough) is that it is not a hard game if you find the right strategy or strategies:(Both these things are explained in game [Nights 1 and 2] and there are no big spoilers from the rest of the recordings on these nights or any other nights)- You need to try and save 50% from 12-3 so you have the other half of battery life from 3-6, which isn't that hard if you know what to do and when to do it.  If you have a strategy that can help you do this, you'll make it to 6 AM usually, and therefore it won't really scare you as you know what to do and how to last the whole night.- If a character is not on one of the cameras they are most likely at a door so it really eliminates any scare tactic there, unless of course, you forget that part of the recording and don't realize that until after you see it.Overall it is a really good game, but it may benefit from having more rooms added without cameras (or ones that have blindspots where the animatronics can hide) so it eliminates the problem I have with the second point.  I'm not sure how it would be possible to fix or change the first issue I have, unless it actually does become very hard for nights 4 and 5, which I have yet to start.  If so, then the first point may not end up being a problem if you are forced to change strategies midway through the playthrough due to losing too much battery life.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												I'm actually very disappointed in this game. It really isn't anything more than a click game. You click to check cameras and you click to close doors. Keep doing that until it's 6am in-game and you're done for the night. Repeat again the next night. Congratulations on completing the game in under an hour.Honestly, I had hoped for way more than it delivered. I was expecting a horror game for PC. What I got was something that wouldn't look out of place on some casual browser-game site. The 'scares' are just jump-scares. There's no tension because there's no need to worry. It's just a question of click until they get too close and then shut the doors till they leave again.It just doesn't live up to the hype.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												Made from the people who brought us the "Paranormal Activity" movies and inspired by Lots-o' from "Toy Story 3", Five Nights at Freddy's is a 1st person game in which you play as a security guard; trying to make his way through life. Little did he know he got the job at the kinkiest bistro in the world.This game provides an adrenaline rushed experience suitable for all the family, all races, all genders and all sexualities - though with its constant lack of white supremacy I find myself constantly assessing my relationship with the game.Positives:+Great storyline.+Amazing voice actors.+Graphics.+Great character developement.+Engaging protagonist.Negatives:-Sad ending.-No DLC.-Lack of white supremacy.Overall a breathtaking game        9/10

content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												I enjoyed the game, even if it is a little short you can always make your custom night and play again and again. The mechanics were well thought out and the game itself was fun to play even if the story was a little weak in itself. the animatronics are cleverly thought out and makes you adapt to each one of them as individual characters rather than lumping them into one big threat, for example Foxy will only come out of pirate cove if you do not watch the cameras(including his camera) often enough or watch them constantly. This forces you to watch the cameras and maintain a balance between reserving your limited power(which constantly dwindles) and keeping an eye on the animatronics lest they try and make a break for your little closet you call a security room and shove you into a costume filled with nice little sharp and point bits of metal. I look forward to the next game this company creates and I can say 100% they have made a fan of them out of me. 10/10 Ready for Freddy.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												If there's one thing to congratulate Five Nights at Freddy's for it's that it succeeds at being intense and oppressive even without the horror elements. The game could easily be about combatting viruses as opposed to the game's animatronics and it would still be as intimidating to play thanks to the management of power.Much as the game loves to tell you otherwise, it's actually not a jump scare showcase. In reality, FNaF is about preventing the most sharp and uneasing jump scares through your effective management of power through the use of doors, your camera and the lights which reveals nearby animatronics. The other jump scares barely warrant as "scares" as they're basically just warnings to make you do the equivalent of a quick time event but in a very organic way that requires you to actually think. I welcomed it greatly, as the actual jump scares are not worth the build up the game gives you (though thus far, I've only died once by animatronic, all the rest have been power outtages). The game relies on you to be able to track the activity of the animatronics which greatly contributes to the fear factor.However, tracking the activity of the animatronics essentially makes the game very much based on trial and error and the animitronics lose much of their creepiness factor once you learn how they operate. The sole animatronic to induce fear to me was Bonnie the Bunny, and it wasn't on account of his appearence (he comes off as silly in many of the camera shots), it's because he quite literally teleports to whatever room his can move into. It makes it near impossible to guess when he will show up outside the Office. Chica and Freddy have specific routes, and you manage how Foxy and Golden Freddy operate. Incidentally, Golden Freddy is a pathetic jump scare which is just unfair to new players. Lift your camera up when he shows up and you'll be fine.Leaving that aside, though, the game does a spectacular job at creating an atmosphere as well as providing gameplay that encourages constant retries. Each night only lasts between ten to fifteen minutes in real time (assuming you don't die), which speaks very well for the game given that it can very quickly establish itself. Even if marred by Bonnie the Bunny and Golden Freddy, the animatronics all have personality and do well to work with the already intense power saving gameplay. It's worth playing simply to say that you've spent a night at Freddy Fazbear's Pizza.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												It's essentially unnecessary for me to write a review of this game as there have been a vast number of reviews written already covering a game that is actually quite simple. So, I'll use this space to discuss what I think Five Night's does well as a horror game.Five Nights takes a very simple horror premise (the siege convention)  places the character in a claustrophobic and unusual setting, and offers the player a slowly decreasing skill to fend off invaders for a specific amount of time. It really is as simple as 'keep the bad guys out' with two buttons. The catch, of course, is that the more you use them, and the more you keep track of where the invaders are, the less ability you have to use what you have to defend yourself (the batteries to those buttons and cameras slowly drain away). The success in this format is in the simplicity of this design itself. Give the player the power to expel the invaders for a short period of time if they use it wisely and sparingly. Use it too much and you'll be safe for a short time but likely perish in the long-term; use it sparingly in order to survive the long-term but let your guard down too much and perish in the short-term.Along with those very simple mechanics Five Nights includes a very creepy and claustrophobic atmosphere. Knowing that there are several animatronic creatures slowly shambling, or in one case running, towards you is itself enough to create a sense of dread. Being able to monitor that progress imperfectly on security cameras that leave some level of ambiguity as to where those creatures are heightens that tension and slowly increases it as time passes each night and the energy you're able to use to defend yourself drains away. The framework that this game is hung on is a very simple one with barebone mechanics. The attention to detail, use of sound, and slowly draining player power unify to create an atmosphere that sets you up to be startled when the creatures pop out. What Five Nights gets right is all of the above, though it's sole gimic is the sudden jump scare. What it does it does well and it doesn't try to be anything that it's not, which makes it perfect for what it is - an enjoyable game that creates tension and then delivers with jump scares. It's also relatively challenging on some of the later levels and can offer the player's a decent challenge. I haven't advanced any further in the series than this as I think that the sequels are just slight variations on this same theme and simple framework and I'm not sure if those games are something that I'm really interested in trying having experienced everything they can offer here. This is a game that has spawned a large number of similar games and has essentially created a sub-genre of simple siege style horror games that has saturated the horror market. Despite that, this is the original and is worth playing if you want to experience a few good jump scares and  see where this type of game became popular.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												I was like, "A $5 dollar new horror game that was supposed to be the scariest of them all? IM BUYING THIS" So then I got it and launched the game (It downloads like in 2 seconds) I saw Freddy on the menu and then I was like, "This game seems fun." I clicked new game, freaked me out, I was only on the first night. Then I was like, "YES! I BEAT NIGHT 1! NIGHT 2 IS GONNA BE EASAY!!!" I had a lot of confidence, although, currently, while I'm writing this, I have none at all. When I got to night 2 the phone rang and the guy was like "You might try to actually take a peak at the cameras right now while I'm speaking..." so I was like, "ok." So I checked the cameras and both Bonnie and Chica were gone. I was like, "No biggie. Let me find them.... There's Bonnie in the dining area... Where's Chica... WHERE'S CHICA!!!!!" And then I looked at the kitchen which is audio only and I heard pots and pans and stuff. I kind of spaced out at the sound for like half a minute and then I was like, "Time to check up on Bonnie..." Then Bonnie wasn't in the dining area anymore. I checked backstage because that's where he likes hiding and licking the camera or something... (dont ask) But he wasn't there. He wasn't anywhere. Then I was like, "Let's check the lights on the doors..." so I put down the camera and then *HORRIFYING SCREAM* and Bonnie shook my screen almost and I almost fell out of my chair. Then I said, "Never playing this game again." The next day I played it. Pretty much Bonnie jumpscared me again. That time I DID actually fall out of my chair. Luckily for some reason there was convienently placed cushion.

												Oooh, this game.Let me put it this way; I read up on all the info about it, looked through the wiki, watched several LPs of it, even looked at the cutesy fan art. And EVEN THEN, I had one hell of a chill down my spine JUST from looking at the PLAY button. Not even in the title screen, and I was already nervous.And rightly so.Never has keeping an eye on something been more terrifying! I swear, everytime I lost track of the robots, I was SO damn close to needing new underwear. It ESPECIALLY does NOT help my nerves when they just disable the cameras! And that's WITHOUT the fox to worry about!Seriously, this has got to be one of, if not THE best horror game of 2014 so far! Kudos to Scott Cawthon for such an amazing, and frightening, experience!
