content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												When I first saw this game on steam greenlight I actually had very high hopes for this, a concept of horror everyone has feared once in their lives at least yet no one has ever done anything about it. Animatronics, these bloody kind you see in children's restaurants, or used to see anyway. I had given this a thumbs up and continued to look through games since this one was indeed a nice path AWAY from those darn slender clones I kept seeing, and my god how this game has grown in popularity which makes me very, and I mean VERY, happy. This focuses on a slightly new form of horror, it's not seeing something chase you, it's not running from the generi monster trying to catch you from behind or such. This game focuses on knowing there is something after you, knowing what is after you, having the item truly traumatic to the human subconscious with something we have all feared once in our lives, and probably the biggest change here. You know it's coming, you can narrow down where they usually close in but can never predict their actions, and you have not only the feeling of pure paranoia, but have this knawing feeling in the back of your head that it is never IF they find you, never IF they  get you, every IF in a scenario that goes against your progress will always become a WHEN. This game is truly outstanding, and if a sequel is truly being made as I have heard rumors of, then it certainly has my wallet on life support out of eagerness of the awaited release date. Likely what I have said might not make sense to some people since I type things a bit oddly, but to sum up what I think, This is a stupendous game, a full 10 out of the option of 10 given. I sincerely hope a sequel is in the making, and I wish the best of luck towards the maker of this game.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												Lets review!This game is intense, and not for your usual survival elements that make big name games what they are.You are confined to a single room. This room has a monitor which provides your only eyesight about Fazbear's Pizza, and two switches; a door switch and a light switch. Your objective is deceptively simple. Survive the night, using these three tools as your only means to see 6 A.M. alive.Might seem easy, at first. The first night will be a breeze, a true tutorial of the game to get comfy. By night 2, you might be surprised to pop open your cameras only to find out one of the animatronics is already out and mucking about.By night 3 you'll understand what real horror is. It isn't in 'Do I have enough bullets', or 'oh damn, I have to outrun this big bad oogy boogy thing'. It's in watching a power gauge go from 100%, and praying to God it doesn't hit 0% before dawn comes. Or hoping Chica will finally go away from the window, while you're trying to maintain three different things and watching your reserves just drop and drop.The jump scares are pretty okay. They'll surprise the hell out of you, and may cause you to scream loudly and in a broad, colorful stream of obscenities. But this is only the icing on a seven layer cake straight from the bakery of Hell. The atmosphere, and tension are the real key factors here. Combined with a resource management scheme that works really well, and becomes significantly harder to deal with, this is a real gem of a game!There are some cons. For instance, your neighbors next door of your apartment will not appreciate the sudden stream of slurs you echo throughout your apartment building. Also, a great deal of the A.I. is either left up to luck itself on whether or not you'll survive, or I somehow was... good, I'm not sure which. Foxy never broke out of Pirate's Cove during my five nights, though he did come sneaking out of the curtain. And Chica decided to jsut take up a five minute vigil outside of my door, which quickly became annoying and cause my only death due to dealing with her while trying to keep an eye on everything else. But at the same time, I'd chalk up such paranoia inducing shennanigans as all part of the experience.Welcome to Freddy's. It's one half skill, and the other half luck. Will yours hold out til 6 in the morning?

content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												I made this purchase after my sister in law was raving about it. I hadn't heard anything about until she opened her mouth and once I heard her words I knew I had to buy it. The game hasn't disappointed yet. I'm only on night 3 but the tension is palpable. I can hear them walking around. I check the cameras and everyone is accounted for. Then every once in a while the Camera's all black out and I'm left with nothing but my own vivid imagination. Are they outside my door? I scan all the cameras and nothing. I shine the light and nothing. It's these little moments that freak me out the most. Not knowing and second guessing myself. The power drains more. What did I do? Will I have enough power to make it through the night? I don't know. I don't know if I want to know. I keep playing though. I'll keep playing till I finish the 5 nights. I think it really might take me 5 nights. I need a day to recuperate from all the stress I feel when playing this game. I love it though. It's not just the jump scares that make it scary.

												Okay, so here it is:You are a night watchman at a chucky cheese that was built on an indian burial ground or something, amd the animatronics want to shove your organs into a suit. So...you have to moniter them on the security cameras, chekc the halls with lights, and if worse comes to worst, close the doors. However, every action with the exception of looking left and right, uses power. Even inaction uses power. You have to survive 5 progressively-worse nights, for 6 hours (6 mins actually). A good way to conserve power is to only use the hall lights, and use the cameras to keep tabs on the characters locations. However, run out of power, and you can kiss your♥♥♥♥♥goodbye. Oh, and at the end of the week, you only get payed 120 bucks, and overtime is an extra 50 cents. I wrote a poem to summerize the game.Roses are red,Violets are blu,Should've worked at Chuck's,Now Im ♥♥♥♥ed.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
												I was not ready for Freddy. Or Bonnie. Or Chica. Or Foxy. Or this game. Or having a mental breakdown. Or buying a new laptop after I threw it out the third floor window (or at least wanting to).10/10, would be unprepared again.  **EDIT**Okay, so you saw my rather silly review of the game above, quite resembling many reviews for this game. Now, having beaten nights 1-6 without cheats, I have a more experienced and balanced view of the quality of Five Nights at Freddy's (I had only beaten Night 1 when I wrote the original review).So: Five Nights At Freddy's. We've all heard the phrase 'Easy to learn, difficult to master', and I don't know if that suits anything more than this game. The gameplay and controls are very, very simple, requiring only the pointing and clicking of the mouse. Using lights, doors and cameras to hinder the villainous animatronics, you must survive five (actually seven including the Custom Night) nights at Freddy's.The biggest two questions that need to be answered about this game are as follows: is it difficult, and is it scary. Yes, and yes. However, even more important are these questions: is it as difficult, and as scary, as everyone makes it out to be? No, and no. Let me elaborate on my  statements.When I originally purchased Five Nights At Freddy's, less than a week ago, I expected to experience one of the scariest and most difficult games ever. A few days later, I beat Night 4 on my first try, and Night 5 on my second. I'm not claiming that it wasn't hard, but I certainly expected a larger challenge. If you have a good strategy and you're quick at executing it, you should get by, though luck can always go away from your favor. It must be noted, though, that the pressure that you have as a result of the impending atmosphere most certainly makes it more difficult to effeciently carry out your strategy. It is a very difficult game, but not as difficult as people make it out to be sometimes (like saying Night 4 is impossible).Now: is it as scary as people say? Also no. The atmosphere is terrifying, the creatures are freaky and the jump scares are truly startling, but I'm afraid that this game could never be as scary as people say, because so many say it's the scariest game of all time. If you watched PewDiePie's reaction to Bonnie peering into his office, you'd think it was absolutely horrifying. In all honesty, it's just makes me give a little shudder, and get back to the game. Plenty of things in this game fall into that same category. Again, please do not get me wrong, this game is very scary. I just doubt it's the scariest game of all time. Actually, the lore and theories behind the game are probably the scariest part (watch the Game Theorist's video about it). Overall, this is a very difficult, very frustrating (in a good way), very tense and suprisingly well designed game, which I highly recommend for horror fanatics or someone looking for a challenge. 9/10, well done Scott, can't wait to play the second.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												When I saw this game I thought "This looks pretty cool, the Idea of weeping angel style animatronic animals is ceepy and could be great to try"............Then I remembered I had a morbid fear of; Mannequins, Statues, anything that looks humanoid that doesn't move...... but then you turn your head away. Then you blink, and oh yes it can!I completed one night with little to no encounters and I was freaking out so much, the atmosphere and the mood were amazing! I've played quite a few horror games and this is in my top list, I'm panicking when I click the play button on Steam because I know whats coming, I am currently on night 2 and I literally can't even...... It gets to a point where I start to get the shakes or I breathe heavily. Have you ever screamed so hard that you trigger an uncontrollable coughing fit, followed by serious throat pains and you then start to lose your voice.....yeah that's what happened to me after my second attempt on the second night, Bonnie the purple giant rabbit jumped me so fast you wouldn't believe, one moment he's there the next....IN MY FACE! And with the loud screech to add to the horror effect.I highly reccommend this game, It's actually great fun desptie the fact you may or may not be able to sleep at night.....or a headache from the loud screeching.... but anyway I say, hey if you want a game to test you're reaction speeds under pressure, this is most definitely the game for you.Well that's just about it really....oh! one last thing I forgot to mention....They're coming. The Mascots are coming for you, but listen -your life could depend on this- don't blink. Don't even blink. Blink and you're dead. They are fast, faster than you could believe. Don't turn your back, don't look away, and don't blink.........Good luck.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
												I was not ready for Freddy. Or Bonnie. Or Chica. Or Foxy. Or this game. Or having a mental breakdown. Or buying a new laptop after I threw it out the third floor window (or at least wanting to).10/10, would be unprepared again.  **EDIT**Okay, so you saw my rather silly review of the game above, quite resembling many reviews for this game. Now, having beaten nights 1-6 without cheats, I have a more experienced and balanced view of the quality of Five Nights at Freddy's (I had only beaten Night 1 when I wrote the original review).So: Five Nights At Freddy's. We've all heard the phrase 'Easy to learn, difficult to master', and I don't know if that suits anything more than this game. The gameplay and controls are very, very simple, requiring only the pointing and clicking of the mouse. Using lights, doors and cameras to hinder the villainous animatronics, you must survive five (actually seven including the Custom Night) nights at Freddy's.The biggest two questions that need to be answered about this game are as follows: is it difficult, and is it scary. Yes, and yes. However, even more important are these questions: is it as difficult, and as scary, as everyone makes it out to be? No, and no. Let me elaborate on my  statements.When I originally purchased Five Nights At Freddy's, less than a week ago, I expected to experience one of the scariest and most difficult games ever. A few days later, I beat Night 4 on my first try, and Night 5 on my second. I'm not claiming that it wasn't hard, but I certainly expected a larger challenge. If you have a good strategy and you're quick at executing it, you should get by, though luck can always go away from your favor. It must be noted, though, that the pressure that you have as a result of the impending atmosphere most certainly makes it more difficult to effeciently carry out your strategy. It is a very difficult game, but not as difficult as people make it out to be sometimes (like saying Night 4 is impossible).Now: is it as scary as people say? Also no. The atmosphere is terrifying, the creatures are freaky and the jump scares are truly startling, but I'm afraid that this game could never be as scary as people say, because so many say it's the scariest game of all time. If you watched PewDiePie's reaction to Bonnie peering into his office, you'd think it was absolutely horrifying. In all honesty, it's just makes me give a little shudder, and get back to the game. Plenty of things in this game fall into that same category. Again, please do not get me wrong, this game is very scary. I just doubt it's the scariest game of all time. Actually, the lore and theories behind the game are probably the scariest part (watch the Game Theorist's video about it). Overall, this is a very difficult, very frustrating (in a good way), very tense and suprisingly well designed game, which I highly recommend for horror fanatics or someone looking for a challenge. 9/10, well done Scott, can't wait to play the second.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												As this game is designed to scare the living daylights out of you, this is a pretty good game. Basically the aim of the game is not to get caught by the animatronic characters of Freddy Fazbear's Pizza (a Pizzaria designed to entertain children) by watching the cameras to see whereabouts in the building they are. Now at first, I thought that sitting in a little office looking at cameras and checking lights outside two side doors was pretty plain, but with this game having the instructions so simple, the experience is terrifying once Bonnie (the purple rabbit character) is almost at your door on night one. Not to mention the amount of jumpscares included in this game, and all of the little sudden noises which activate your 'Paranoid Mode' because that the game mainly runs in complete silence (apart from the noise of energy and electricity in your office).Once you've had a few hours of playing this game, though, you can get used to all of the noises and jumpscares, and go through the rest of the game with ease by just having to be aware of where the characters are in the building without having a sense of fear towards it because that you're so used to it. But that can take a while, so if you want to overcome your fear of being watched, being hunted, or just of animatronics, have the bravory to play this game non stop for a long time. But if you only want to achieve getting to the end and completing this game, that's fine, I hope you're ready for Freddy.I definitely don't recommend this game for people who have just gotten into the Horror genre in gaming. Start off with something like Slender, and then maybe move onto RPG Horrors (because you're more aware of your surroundings), then probably Amnesia, and if you really want to, try this game out after that (or you could just completetly ignore my advice and play F.N.A.F. with no Horror game experience, so you'll have a much higher possibility of being effected more by the game e.g. being scared in your home because you heard a little noise like the house creaking, or having the game stuck on your head more so you believe that if you turn around, Freddy's going to scream in your face and kill you).This game really plays with your senses, and that's what I like in a Horror game, it makes you afraid to continue, it makes you feel a sense of dread, it activates your 'Parinoid Mode' much more, and (believe me) it stays activated even when you're not playing the game. This game has made me a lot more paranoid, and I really like that Scott Cawthon managed to achieve that feature in the game.I always look for a Horror game that makes you scared to move on, that makes you feel so many unwanted fear-related emotions, that makes you wonder why you bought the game in the first place, that makes you paranoid, that makes you scared to be by yourself, that makes you love the daylight more than ever, that makes you afraid of looking down a hallway or outside, or even out the door into another room.And Five Nights At Freddy's has really got all of those features, easily - well done and thank you Scott for making this game, it brought a lot of smiles and fearful frowns to people's computer screens, and we all are looking forward to Five Nights At Freddy's 2.Thank you so much for reading this review, I hope you enjoyed reading it, and I hope you enjoy/have enjoyed playing F.N.A.F. as much as I have.~Pet

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												When I first saw this game on steam greenlight I actually had very high hopes for this, a concept of horror everyone has feared once in their lives at least yet no one has ever done anything about it. Animatronics, these bloody kind you see in children's restaurants, or used to see anyway. I had given this a thumbs up and continued to look through games since this one was indeed a nice path AWAY from those darn slender clones I kept seeing, and my god how this game has grown in popularity which makes me very, and I mean VERY, happy. This focuses on a slightly new form of horror, it's not seeing something chase you, it's not running from the generi monster trying to catch you from behind or such. This game focuses on knowing there is something after you, knowing what is after you, having the item truly traumatic to the human subconscious with something we have all feared once in our lives, and probably the biggest change here. You know it's coming, you can narrow down where they usually close in but can never predict their actions, and you have not only the feeling of pure paranoia, but have this knawing feeling in the back of your head that it is never IF they find you, never IF they  get you, every IF in a scenario that goes against your progress will always become a WHEN. This game is truly outstanding, and if a sequel is truly being made as I have heard rumors of, then it certainly has my wallet on life support out of eagerness of the awaited release date. Likely what I have said might not make sense to some people since I type things a bit oddly, but to sum up what I think, This is a stupendous game, a full 10 out of the option of 10 given. I sincerely hope a sequel is in the making, and I wish the best of luck towards the maker of this game.

												Five Nights at Freddy's an original Indie game that has sprouted into 2 more♥♥♥♥♥♥games and a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ fanbase. I dont hate this game, I'm just very disapointed, it was a horror game that had so much potential yet finished with a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ jumpscare, yes, it becomes a challenge of stress and power, but it will eventually pass on to a game with jumpscares, and the fact that somehow, it turned into furry convention 2014 is super disapointing, now I know i'll get a bunch of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ comments becuase the fanbase isnt and older that 8 but still, thats another thing, Scott, if you have a bunch of 8 yearolds playing your game and not getting scared, doesn't that make you feel like you could of done better? content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												I didn't think I'd be scared of animatronics, but there I was,♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥my pants on night one because Foxy jumped me since I was too stupid and afraid to do anything. Now I can say I'm pretty scared of animatronics. This game is great, not perfect, but it's definitely a satisfying and refreshing take on the horror genre. The controls and gameplay are simple, but it does such a good job at instilling sheer panic and paranoia, that it becomes much harder than it seems. You are forced to fight against your own sense of fear and vulnerabilty in order to save power. The story too is actually very interesting and haunting in itself, especially once you play the later games (fnaf 2/3) as well. Only 'issue' really is that it doesn't take long to learn the patterns and behaviors of the animatronics, meaning the game becomes more predictable and less scary. It's not too hard to develop a strategy to easily make it through all six nights. However, after all six nights, the game does offer a custom night mode, where you can take on the dreaded 4/20 mode if you dare. It's great because, although it is very challenging and frustrating, it adds replayability of the game and it's very rewarding once you get your strategy down and beat it. All-in-all this game is solid and I definitely recommend it. Well done Scott!

content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												It's essentially unnecessary for me to write a review of this game as there have been a vast number of reviews written already covering a game that is actually quite simple. So, I'll use this space to discuss what I think Five Night's does well as a horror game.Five Nights takes a very simple horror premise (the siege convention)  places the character in a claustrophobic and unusual setting, and offers the player a slowly decreasing skill to fend off invaders for a specific amount of time. It really is as simple as 'keep the bad guys out' with two buttons. The catch, of course, is that the more you use them, and the more you keep track of where the invaders are, the less ability you have to use what you have to defend yourself (the batteries to those buttons and cameras slowly drain away). The success in this format is in the simplicity of this design itself. Give the player the power to expel the invaders for a short period of time if they use it wisely and sparingly. Use it too much and you'll be safe for a short time but likely perish in the long-term; use it sparingly in order to survive the long-term but let your guard down too much and perish in the short-term.Along with those very simple mechanics Five Nights includes a very creepy and claustrophobic atmosphere. Knowing that there are several animatronic creatures slowly shambling, or in one case running, towards you is itself enough to create a sense of dread. Being able to monitor that progress imperfectly on security cameras that leave some level of ambiguity as to where those creatures are heightens that tension and slowly increases it as time passes each night and the energy you're able to use to defend yourself drains away. The framework that this game is hung on is a very simple one with barebone mechanics. The attention to detail, use of sound, and slowly draining player power unify to create an atmosphere that sets you up to be startled when the creatures pop out. What Five Nights gets right is all of the above, though it's sole gimic is the sudden jump scare. What it does it does well and it doesn't try to be anything that it's not, which makes it perfect for what it is - an enjoyable game that creates tension and then delivers with jump scares. It's also relatively challenging on some of the later levels and can offer the player's a decent challenge. I haven't advanced any further in the series than this as I think that the sequels are just slight variations on this same theme and simple framework and I'm not sure if those games are something that I'm really interested in trying having experienced everything they can offer here. This is a game that has spawned a large number of similar games and has essentially created a sub-genre of simple siege style horror games that has saturated the horror market. Despite that, this is the original and is worth playing if you want to experience a few good jump scares and  see where this type of game became popular.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												I was like, "A $5 dollar new horror game that was supposed to be the scariest of them all? IM BUYING THIS" So then I got it and launched the game (It downloads like in 2 seconds) I saw Freddy on the menu and then I was like, "This game seems fun." I clicked new game, freaked me out, I was only on the first night. Then I was like, "YES! I BEAT NIGHT 1! NIGHT 2 IS GONNA BE EASAY!!!" I had a lot of confidence, although, currently, while I'm writing this, I have none at all. When I got to night 2 the phone rang and the guy was like "You might try to actually take a peak at the cameras right now while I'm speaking..." so I was like, "ok." So I checked the cameras and both Bonnie and Chica were gone. I was like, "No biggie. Let me find them.... There's Bonnie in the dining area... Where's Chica... WHERE'S CHICA!!!!!" And then I looked at the kitchen which is audio only and I heard pots and pans and stuff. I kind of spaced out at the sound for like half a minute and then I was like, "Time to check up on Bonnie..." Then Bonnie wasn't in the dining area anymore. I checked backstage because that's where he likes hiding and licking the camera or something... (dont ask) But he wasn't there. He wasn't anywhere. Then I was like, "Let's check the lights on the doors..." so I put down the camera and then *HORRIFYING SCREAM* and Bonnie shook my screen almost and I almost fell out of my chair. Then I said, "Never playing this game again." The next day I played it. Pretty much Bonnie jumpscared me again. That time I DID actually fall out of my chair. Luckily for some reason there was convienently placed cushion.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
In BriefNope.  So much nope.Most valuable resource: the unique, disempowering game design.Of interest to: people who want a really unusual survival horror experience, or who enjoy feeling helpless.Never.  Again.  Nope.  No.  Done.This game has one very well designed feature though: upon hitting escape the game immediately shuts down, no questions asked, which is great because in my panic that is what I did, and that is the result I wanted.Five Nights at Freddy's is terrifying.  I will not be playing it again (maybe), but I give it mad props for being the most innovative, creative, inspired take on survival horror at a time when there are so many games out there just trying to be Amnesia or Slender.  Five Nights at Freddy's is terrifyingly original - and that's a large part of the reason I was completely lacking in any immunity to even the most basic scares this game dropped on me and I had to quit out at 4am on the second day because I was having heart palpitations.The brilliance of the design here is that unlike every other survival horror game I've ever played, in Five Nights at Freddy's you do not move,.  You stay exactly where you are in the one room with minimal ability to change your point of view, monitoring the goings on on the security cameras, listening to noises, flicking on the lights to see if anyone's outside your room and if it's worth spending electricity to close the safety door - and through the whole experience you cannot move, you can't run, you can't hide, you can't do anything at all except stand there and wait, and watch, and listen, and know that eventually they're going to come.   It is a uniquely terrifying; in every other game you can give in to your urge to run (whether that's a good idea or not) but in this game you literally cannot.  That instinctive reaction, that self-preserving power is taken away from you, and that fact makes the game so much more unsettling, just that fact that your natural instinct is gone.  When for the first time I flicked on a light and saw an animatronic standing there, stationary, leering at me, I panicked.  In any other game I would have taken shelter, hidden, prepared to fight, whatever, but here?  I was paralysed because none of my instincts knew to do anything other than move.I have often said that indie gaming brings creativity and innovation in much the same was as structured poetry does.  When you have to work within the rigid limitations afforded by your budget and timeline, you find ways to really drill down and focus on the most important aspects, the critical features that are essential for your game.  In Five Nights at Freddy's they took a game with a simple, no-physics point-and-click interface, and handful of static visuals and a whole lot of atmosphere and made the scariest experience I've ever had in front of a computer.

I do absoloutly nothing but check on foxy, check the doors, and honk freddy's nose on the poster, I was visited by bonnie twice, first time he came, I closed the door, and he left, then the next tim he stayed at the door for about one and a half minutes. Chica stayed in the bathroom/kitchen. Freddy stayed on stage, and foxy just looked at me through the curtains.Second night. Only bonnie chica, and foxy were my predators. Bonnie came first, maybe a couple seconds after the call ended. Bonnie stayed for maybe two minutes, then left. Chica game for a surprise, and I shut the door and she went and cried in the kitchen forever. Foxy made one attempt but failed horibly, because the door was already closed because bonnie had been there. Bonnie came back and stayed at the door forever, and it drained all my power. Luckily freddy's jumpscare was cut short by the "6 Am" Message. I also got the rare screenshot of the 3 crying children posters in the hall.Third night. First night I died, bonnie came around a lot, but never stayed for too long. While no one was around I was too dumb playing around with freddys nose on the poster to notice freddy was actualy coming fter me. After a while I realise freddy was gone, I couldn't find him anywhere, then I go out of my camera because id went out and I had a birthday surprise by Freddy ♥♥♥♥boy. Fourth night, I got seconds in and then foxy killed me, That sucked. But the next time it was too easy, only freddy and bonnie came by, freddy was no trouble and neither was bonnie, so it was pretty easy.Fifth nightI'm crying now. I've tried several times but freddy won't leave me alone. No matter how much I beg, I close the door, he doesn't leave, and I run out of power, I open them for a second, freddy kills me. I am so close, I only have a hour left, and 10% I decide that since freddy was not in the doorway I would open it. I've been opening and closing it before now, and little did I know freddy was already in the room. I check the camera, no freddy, anywhere. I knew the exact places the animetronics could appear, and freddy was either in the kitchen, or nowhere at all. I exit out of camera and kills me, it was only seconds till I could have won. I beg, I pray, I make teddy bear sacrifaces, nothing works. I honk freddys poster nose, I get a bet farther than normal, but still can't win. I've played 116 minutes. I originaly owned it just to show kids how bad♥♥♥♥♥I was, but ended up playing in front of some friends, I've screamed and cried, and even smacked a friend in the face by accident. This game has ruined my life, yet I am addicted. God, any god, or even no god, I need a lot of a help.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												I originally watched Markiplier and various other youtubers play it,entertaining millions with how much they got scared,and I decided to play it for myself,and after playing it some,I can see why they got so scared x)The game hardly has a plot really,it's one of those short indie horror games that doesn't really need a plot,but it centers around an unnamed worker who takes the night shift at a restaurant called Freddy Fazbear's Pizza,with some interesting(to put it nicely)things happening during the night shift.The gameplay is simple,you have a camera monitor that you can use to switch between security cameras in the place,you can close/open the electrical doors in your office to keep the animatronics from coming in,and lights to see if they're outside the room. All of these different things at your disposal are important in their own way for protecting yourself from the animatronics and surviving each night.In addition to the 5 nights in the game,there's an additional 6th Night,and even a 7th Night,where you can customize the AI to make it easy as heck or as hard as The Impossible Game.The atmosphere is REALLY well done,and it gives you a feeling of tension,panic,and anticipation,which is really effective in scaring you.The music is pretty cool,tho the game mostly relies on ambiance and atmosphere.Overall,while this game is pretty simple,it's one of those games that while simple,can still scare the crap out of you.9/10 from me :)(UPDATE Nov. 14,2014-Just watched FNAF 2 on vid for my first time ever so far,and I was ♥♥♥♥ing fearing for my life. I'll def be getting FNAF 2 when I get my laptop for Christmas ^-^)(UPDATE Jan. 1,2015: just beat night 5 :D)(UPDATE Feb 21,2015: Use this strategy on 4/20 mode that I use if you have trouble,it helped me get very far in:Keep the camera mostly on E Hall Corner,that way you won't have to shut the right door every time you check the camera,which would waste powerWhen Chica is at the door,check Pirate Cove quickly,then back to E Hall CornerAfter 2 AM, check Pirate Cove at any random time of your choosing(when you do this,close the right door so Freddy doesn't come in)If the curtains are wide open,go to the W Hall to trigger Foxy running,then go immediately out and shut the left door(also have the right door closed when you do this,otherwise Freddy will come in and kill you)Check both lights,if Bonnie or Chica is at the door,close the door,once their gone,open the door(UPDATE Feb 21,2015: Just beat 4/20 mode,I'm literally shaking)(UPDATE Feb 28,2015: Completed a"speedrun"of nights 1-5 with 1 death on night 5,end time: 54:16.04)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
Good Guy DollRemember the chucky movies?A creepy killer doll is on the loose and out for murder. It spawned a franchise spanning 6 movies (so far...)and if these movies did one thing well, it was to create the world's creepiest little plastic killer  ever! That is until now..."Chucky" CheeseFive Nights at Freddy's places you in the role of a security guard working the "dead" night shift at Freddy Fazbear's Pizza.A family friendly pizza place popular for kids parties and famous for its animatronic  robots, Freddy Fazbear and his pals. These happy, clappy, little fur covered robots entertain the kids during the day but seem to have a tendency to wonder the dark and empty rooms and corridors at night.Puppet MasterThat's where you come in, the job of night security guard has suspiciously become vacant and you're the lucky applicant.Starting the game, you will find yourself sitting in a cramped little security office surrounded by CCTV monitors, a phone,  a door on either side of you and couple of light switches. It's a pretty oppressive setting to start with, but before too long the phone will ring and you'll start to get an idea of the situation you've gotten yourself into.KISS PrincipleThe game-play itself couldn't be simpler. You flick between grey, fuzzy security feeds, watching out for anything unusual. You view the empty tables, the dark corridors, the animatronics room. You'll get your first glimpse of the "puppets" themselves.You remember how I said earlier that the Chucky doll from the Childs Play moves was creepy?Well the unnerving smiles leering through the metal and fur present on these animatronics captures that sense of menace perfectly, but there was only one chucky, here you'll find yourself stalked by a few of the creepy buggers!The only other controls you have beside flicking through the CCTV screens, are the door controls (you can lock yourself in your office) and the door lights (CCTV doesn't quite cover the dark access to your office, A blind spot which can prove fatal.)It's behind You!Wait, did you just say fatal?Oh yes, Freddy and his friends have a habit of wondering around at night, and should they manage to find their way into your little office... well.. . It's game over man!So why don't you just turn on your lights, lock the doors and wait till morning?It's a question of power management. You only have a limited amount of electricity you can utilise throughout the night.Keeping the lights on drains power, keeping the doors locked drains power and trust me, you don't want to be out of power when you see  that creepy bear leering into the security camera just outside your office!SurpriseDon't go in expecting a triple A release here or you will be disappointed, what you essential get for your money are a series of static screens you can flick between and some creepy audio, but this bare bones description doesn't do the experience justice.With such a simple premise and game mechanics it's a surprise that this game works, but it does.This is a title that is more than the sum of its parts.The tension builds as your power reserves dwindle. You'll see the cuddly killers creeping ever closer. You'll have your  finger ready on the door lock button, just one more second, just one more second before you hit it....This game oozes atmosphere, It's as creepy as hell and it WILL make you jump!If you're looking for a cheap scare that you can enjoy over the course of an hour or so, then you can't go far wrong with Five Nights At Freddy's.Childs PlayPlay with headphones,Play in the darkPlay on your ownPlay Five Nights At Freddy'sFor the full review and others please click HERE[www.review-well.com]

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
In BriefNope.  So much nope.Most valuable resource: the unique, disempowering game design.Of interest to: people who want a really unusual survival horror experience, or who enjoy feeling helpless.Never.  Again.  Nope.  No.  Done.This game has one very well designed feature though: upon hitting escape the game immediately shuts down, no questions asked, which is great because in my panic that is what I did, and that is the result I wanted.Five Nights at Freddy's is terrifying.  I will not be playing it again (maybe), but I give it mad props for being the most innovative, creative, inspired take on survival horror at a time when there are so many games out there just trying to be Amnesia or Slender.  Five Nights at Freddy's is terrifyingly original - and that's a large part of the reason I was completely lacking in any immunity to even the most basic scares this game dropped on me and I had to quit out at 4am on the second day because I was having heart palpitations.The brilliance of the design here is that unlike every other survival horror game I've ever played, in Five Nights at Freddy's you do not move,.  You stay exactly where you are in the one room with minimal ability to change your point of view, monitoring the goings on on the security cameras, listening to noises, flicking on the lights to see if anyone's outside your room and if it's worth spending electricity to close the safety door - and through the whole experience you cannot move, you can't run, you can't hide, you can't do anything at all except stand there and wait, and watch, and listen, and know that eventually they're going to come.   It is a uniquely terrifying; in every other game you can give in to your urge to run (whether that's a good idea or not) but in this game you literally cannot.  That instinctive reaction, that self-preserving power is taken away from you, and that fact makes the game so much more unsettling, just that fact that your natural instinct is gone.  When for the first time I flicked on a light and saw an animatronic standing there, stationary, leering at me, I panicked.  In any other game I would have taken shelter, hidden, prepared to fight, whatever, but here?  I was paralysed because none of my instincts knew to do anything other than move.I have often said that indie gaming brings creativity and innovation in much the same was as structured poetry does.  When you have to work within the rigid limitations afforded by your budget and timeline, you find ways to really drill down and focus on the most important aspects, the critical features that are essential for your game.  In Five Nights at Freddy's they took a game with a simple, no-physics point-and-click interface, and handful of static visuals and a whole lot of atmosphere and made the scariest experience I've ever had in front of a computer.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
Description:Five Nights at Freddy's is a horror game... but it isn't scary. In FNaF you work at "Freddy Fazbear's Pizza", a happy little pizza place with four anamatronics: Freddy, Bonnie, Chica, And Foxy. But you work as a night guard, and in the night, the anamatronics try to kill you.My Thoughts:Gameplay: 15/100Music: 40/100Visuals: 65/100Story: 30/100Overall: 20/100.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												Five Nights never really catched my attention. At first it seemed like another typical jump-scare game that Youtubers will just overreact about in videos. Once MatPat released his theory on the story, my interest began to grow. I started searching stuff about the game and at the peek of it all, I bought it on Steam.The gameplay is pretty simple, you just have to monitor the animatronics at night for 6 in-game hours and keep them out from the security room you are at. You have a camera that shows most of the building to you, 2 doors that you can close and 2 lights that you can turn on to see 2 o fthe animatronics in case you can't find them on the camera. The real kicker though is that EVERYTHING DRAINS POWER. Power is basically your best friend while playing the game and it drains at a moderately slow rate when you don't use anything. The more stressed you are and francticly try to check the camera and close the doors, the more power it drains. This makes the game an interesting combination of surviving the animatronics, while at the same time trying to not run out of time. pretty unique as far as horror games go.Speaking of horror, this game seriously has none. I am a complete ♥♥♥♥♥ when it comes to any type of scare, but this game was a walk in the park pretty much. Not even close to the scariest game ever as everyone tries to say. I will, however, say that it was mostly because of the way the game is made. It is possible to beat the game without a single jumpscare, as long as you have the skill to do it. This is good, because your own skill dictates the scares of the game. Very cool.Let's talk about the nights, shall we?The first 3 or so nights are pretty easy if you know what you are doing. When night 4 comes, it gets harder. Not only do you have to deal with Bonnie and Chica, which can sometimes overstay at your doors and drain too much power, but you have to deal with Foxy, who can quickly run at your office and can get you killed if you don't check him often. Freddy also becomes a threat and can be a problem if let to go close to your office. There are plenty of strategies out there on how to beat nights 3-6 and it's even possible to make Freddy and Foxy stay at their starting points the entire night, making it quite easy. Night 7 is a custom night that you can change to your heart's desire. It's mostly just a nice end-game addition to help you practice, but if you beat the hardest possible setup, you pretty much have beat the game 100%.The presentation is another thing where this game excells at. The dark and eerie athmosphere really has that feel of being alone at night. In the end, the game is great. I think that it's a good entry point for people who are interested in horror and it has great mechanics, great athmosphere and a story that makes you think.If you are interested, give it a go. It's not the easiest of games, especially when it comes to the later nights, but it is well worth it just for the experience.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												Why do I have to be ashamed to admit I enjoy these games? The fanbase has gone to complete crap, and no where seems to be safe. These youngin's are trying to ruin my horror games! Seriously, don't bother trying to find a good community. Without any of that into consideration, the game is good. (Depending on who you are.) As for the horror part, it's great. It's dripping in atmosphere, and while you could call it "jumpscare-bait," the jumpscares would be meaningless without a good build up. The sound design is superb, it's haunting and the game rewards you for listening closely as most of the sounds mean something. The gameplay is great and very original. It's very well thought-out, you can really tell that a lot of effort went into making all the mechanics. That being said, many people don't like it and just feels as if it's micro-management. The animatronics all move and act mostly randomly which is great and unexpected in Nights 1-4, but on 5 it just feels unfair. You can play the game perfectly, yet it'll screw you over because... why not? It feels like a fake added difficulty, when I die I should feel like I made a mistake! Not because the random number generator screwed me over!The visuals are simple and not overly detailed, yet they are good enough and give the game it's own style and character. Each room is well put together and can be really spooky, especially at night! The graphics are all pre-rendered images, and while it is rough around the edges in places, it isn't too easy to notice. It's done very well to trick you into think it's actually 3D. (Though more observant players will notice.) The story is what some would call the only part worth playing in this game. The story is presented very well, and is very mysterious. It's a lot of fun to try and put the pieces together and search for clues throughout the series. Yet, despit what some think, the story itself is very simplistic. It's not about the destination, it's about the journey.Even with all that, it is far from perfect. The jumpscares look laughably silly, and it could remove all the built up tension you had. The game is well designed, but not well made. There is no pause button. Pushing escape instantly exits the game. (Like, what?) There are no options what-so-ever. (No subtitles for people who like them) There are no resolution options, the game is not widescreen so if you play it fullscreen on any monitor that isn't decades old, it'll just stretch the image. This is 2015, widescreen should be the standard. If you can ignore it's technical flaws, the community, and want a unique and fresh horror experience, play this game. If you've seen videos and don't think you'll enjoy it, then you probably won't, so don't bother. And if you do enjoy the game, then I recommend the sequels!The sequels are great, and they don't feel like shameless cash-ins. Each game brings a new gameplay twist making each one stand out as it's own game. I say you should give all of them a try, but if you only want to try one I would say go with the fourth one. It's really good. (Unfortunatly, they all suffer from the same flaws as this one. Except for the jumpscares, those got better to the point of actually being freaky.)

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												Its kind of like Night Trap, except rather the teenage girls running around, theres a bunch of Chuck-E-Cheese animatronics trying to get into your office and touch your butt.Which can be considered a negative or a positive depending on the kind of sick the part of the internet your on is.You sit around in your office while watching the security camera feed to see how close the animatronic animals are to touching your butt, and if they get close enough to stare at you threw the door way, you slam your military grade door that a Chuck-E-Cheese had installed for some reason right in their face. But don't screw around with the doors too much or you'll loose all your power, the doors will open ( because the doors are closed by magnet like things, that require power to function. They have these types of doors installed in military bases so if power cuts out the doors will automatically open and the people won't be trapped inside.  Or something like that. That's why the doors drain power.)and Freddy will touch your butt, and it will be game over. I didn't personally find this game scary, but that's because I didn't really grow up around the age of spooky Chuck-E-Cheese animatronics and I'm not stressed out too easily. But I do, however, enjoy playing the game as a game, as in I genuinely find the gameplay fun, challenging and creative. And I can see how people would be scared by this game if they grew up with the early 80's or 90's (Not entirley sure when the animatronics were at their most grotesque and uncanny) and they are generally a very anxious person. But there are some negatives here, such as the fact that the cameras themselves are almost entirley useless. The animatronics locations are basically meaningless, as they seem to be able to jump to right outside your office in a instant on later nights, Infact the creator of the game, Scott Cawthon, even added an animatronic in, that's entire purpose is to ensure you don't abandon the cameras. I feel like this could have been fixed by a system that would cause they animatronics to gradually become more and more active, unless you watched them all frequently and sufficiently. Also the game doesn't really have alot of gameplay too it, once you beat it there is really no point on coming back to it. Its not going to be scary and not going to be fun to play. But hey its base price is five dollars, what do you expect really. I hear alot of people complaining that this game is a "jumpscare fest" which is in my opinion, a very stupid statement to make. You only ever get jumpscared when you get your butt touched, or more accurately, die and get a game over. As if its a punisment for screwing up, something you had complete control of. Unlike something like Slender, where you get jumpscared for walking around a corner, or turning around.So to conclude, I don't really find this game that scary, but I do find it a fun idea excuted nicely, so take that for what you  can take that for what you will. Thanks.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												Five Nights at Freddy's is a simple game that banks on jump-scares.Each animatronic character that you have to monitor in this game has its own personality and behavior. You have to learn these to begin to predict where to monitor and when and at what points to toggle the door locks and lights. This requires many play-throughs to get it right.The thing that makes this game worthwhile, to me, is how much they were able to do with such a limited tool set. There's really no animation. You're just looking at still images through a camera that pans side to side. Instead of animations, cameras black out momentarily. You only ever see still images. And yet, you still get this quirky story with a game play that requires replays and observation to eventually master.If you're looking for a real horror or survival game, this isn't it. If you're looking for very deep game play, this isn't it. If you're looking for two or three hours of trying to beat-the-pattern with the occasional startle (even after the tenth time, I still get a little jolt), then it's worth grabbing. I got it at half price and it's worth that. I think the default five bucks is just about right at the limit of a reasonable price.I just find it so damn clever how much they did with so little. If you're uncertain about the game, it's still worth looking into at a lower price point.

It's done very well to trick you into think it's actually 3D. (Though more observant players will notice.) The story is what some would call the only part worth playing in this game. The story is presented very well, and is very mysterious. It's a lot of fun to try and put the pieces together and search for clues throughout the series. Yet, despit what some think, the story itself is very simplistic. It's not about the destination, it's about the journey.Even with all that, it is far from perfect. The jumpscares look laughably silly, and it could remove all the built up tension you had. The game is well designed, but not well made. There is no pause button. Pushing escape instantly exits the game. (Like, what?) There are no options what-so-ever. (No subtitles for people who like them) There are no resolution options, the game is not widescreen so if you play it fullscreen on any monitor that isn't decades old, it'll just stretch the image. This is 2015, widescreen should be the standard. If you can ignore it's technical flaws, the community, and want a unique and fresh horror experience, play this game. If you've seen videos and don't think you'll enjoy it, then you probably won't, so don't bother. And if you do enjoy the game, then I recommend the sequels!The sequels are great, and they don't feel like shameless cash-ins. Each game brings a new gameplay twist making each one stand out as it's own game. I say you should give all of them a try, but if you only want to try one I would say go with the fourth one. It's really good. (Unfortunatly, they all suffer from the same flaws as this one. Except for the jumpscares, those got better to the point of actually being freaky.)

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												Its kind of like Night Trap, except rather the teenage girls running around, theres a bunch of Chuck-E-Cheese animatronics trying to get into your office and touch your butt.Which can be considered a negative or a positive depending on the kind of sick the part of the internet your on is.You sit around in your office while watching the security camera feed to see how close the animatronic animals are to touching your butt, and if they get close enough to stare at you threw the door way, you slam your military grade door that a Chuck-E-Cheese had installed for some reason right in their face. But don't screw around with the doors too much or you'll loose all your power, the doors will open ( because the doors are closed by magnet like things, that require power to function. They have these types of doors installed in military bases so if power cuts out the doors will automatically open and the people won't be trapped inside.  Or something like that. That's why the doors drain power.)and Freddy will touch your butt, and it will be game over. I didn't personally find this game scary, but that's because I didn't really grow up around the age of spooky Chuck-E-Cheese animatronics and I'm not stressed out too easily. But I do, however, enjoy playing the game as a game, as in I genuinely find the gameplay fun, challenging and creative. And I can see how people would be scared by this game if they grew up with the early 80's or 90's (Not entirley sure when the animatronics were at their most grotesque and uncanny) and they are generally a very anxious person. But there are some negatives here, such as the fact that the cameras themselves are almost entirley useless. The animatronics locations are basically meaningless, as they seem to be able to jump to right outside your office in a instant on later nights, Infact the creator of the game, Scott Cawthon, even added an animatronic in, that's entire purpose is to ensure you don't abandon the cameras. I feel like this could have been fixed by a system that would cause they animatronics to gradually become more and more active, unless you watched them all frequently and sufficiently. Also the game doesn't really have alot of gameplay too it, once you beat it there is really no point on coming back to it. Its not going to be scary and not going to be fun to play. But hey its base price is five dollars, what do you expect really. I hear alot of people complaining that this game is a "jumpscare fest" which is in my opinion, a very stupid statement to make. You only ever get jumpscared when you get your butt touched, or more accurately, die and get a game over. As if its a punisment for screwing up, something you had complete control of. Unlike something like Slender, where you get jumpscared for walking around a corner, or turning around.So to conclude, I don't really find this game that scary, but I do find it a fun idea excuted nicely, so take that for what you  can take that for what you will. Thanks.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2014
												I ignored this title when it first appeared on the Steam catalogue as it didn't really seem to be my kind of thing, but after a friend suggested that I look it up properly, I proceeded to watch the trailers and thought that it would be worth a go... why not? I had a look around the net and got it for 50% off on HumbleBundle.com.First of all, I am really glad that I took the time to play Five Nights at Freddy's, even though it's not the type of game or genre I would normally go for, it turned out to be a lot of fun and actually pretty scary, even though you know what's coming after a couple of play-throughs, the game still has an ability to keep you on the edge of your seat. Five Nights at Freddy's is a simple horror game where you take up night shifts as a security guard for Freddy's resturant, strange and frightening things being to happen when the animatronics seem to develop a mind of their own after 12AM. You have a limited amount of power and thus, very limited visibility while you struggle to decide if you want to keep the cameras/lights on or the doors kept sealed. I won't go into too much detail as I don't want to spoil it for any of you. This turned out to be a great little Indie Game and the way it has soared in popularity in such a short amount of time is astounding, but I am glad that this is getting a lot of recognition. Even though the concept is simple, the game itself is fantastic and a lot of fun, especially at 2AM in the morning with all of the lights off and volume on full. Even though it's somewhat of a short game with simple controls, it is well worth the £1.99 I spent on it (I'd say it's worth the full £3.99 too) and I am really looking forward to a sequal or any future updates. If you've been keeping an eye on this but are unsure about spending £3.99 on something short, see if you can find it on sale somewhere. Take my word for it, it's brilliant. This game proves beyond a doubt that simplicity in a game can be very effective.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												--WARNING--This review represents my own, objective opinion about this game. This means, that I will not praise the game for the good things and don't mention it's flawes, but I also won't talk only bad things about the game to make it look completly worthless. As far as the review goes, it will have spoilers, so i'd recommend either reading on, if you don't have a problem with that or simply ignore this review. Viewer Discretion Advised.--Introduction--Five Night's at Freddy is a Horror Point-&-Click Adventure game made by one developer (Scott Cawthon).The game reviewed alot of positive reviews by a lot of people and already was Let's Played by several big Let's Players.--Plot--The plot is very simple in the basic. You are Mike Schmidt who's going to work for the Freddy Fazzbear's Pizza as a Night Guard for a week during the summer from 12AM untill 6AM/ a day. Your Job is to watch the animatronics (the main attraction of the Pizzarea) as they are wandering around at night and are not allowed to be shut down or they will lock themselves.This and many other advises and mentions about certain events are being told by a guy on the Phone, who's the only ally for the player, you reciev every night untill the 4th night. He tells right in the first night that the animatronics might come to your office and might mistake you for being an animatronic without a costume and, since this is against the rules, you'll be forced by the animatronics into a costume, which has wires and beams, and won't fit a human body in, resulting in your death. The only defense the player has are 2 doors (1 to the left and 1 to the right), the lights near the doors for the blind spots and your camera to track them down.--Gameplay--The game is being controlled only by the mouse and the only interaction you have are the 4 buttons in your office and the monitor, from which you can switch through different camera feeds. As mentioned earlier, you control with the buttons the doors and the light in the hallways outside the doors. To make things more "difficult" you only have a limited amout of power you can use to protect yourself. That means that closing doors, using the lights and cameras consume power. The more things you use at the same time the quicker the power depletes. If your power is completly consumed, you die unless you are close to 6AM and still have some seconds to have a chance to get to the next night. There are a total of 4 (with "Golden Freddy" 5) animatronics you have to watch for and each of them are more or less unique in their aproach. The first active animatronics will be Bonnie (the blue bunny) and Chica (the yellow chicken). They will roam randomly through the building and will sometimes aproach your office. The further you get in the nights, the more active they'll get. The next animatronic is Foxy (The Pirate-Fox) who's malfunctioning and is "out of order" in his cove. He is the most easylie predictable animatronic if you know his pattern (although that is also random which means you wont know exactly when he is going to attack). the 4th. being freddy and, in later nights, the most agressive animatronic if not dealt with. The 5th. being Golden Freddy, but there must be certain events activated to summon him, which is in the most cases very rare and can be avoided very easy.If you die in this game, then your death will always be a jumpscare, which will be more or less predictable, and you have to start the night from the beginning. And there is no "Pause" function.--Things I like about this game--One thing the game is realy good at is building up tense. The feeling, that an animatronic will attack at any moment and , if you don't watch carefully you'll be punished with a Jumpscare, can happen every single moment. This works pretty good with the random mechanics, since every night is different from the previous, even on new attempts. There is also a form of balance in it to prevent abuses of certain mechanics to get through the game. The strongest element of the game is the fact, that it has plenty room for theories which can tease the player to speculate about with others.I actualy used more time to read theories and making my own theories then playing the game (which is actualy not something good, but i will talk about this later).--Things I don't like about this game--As I mentioned earlier that the game has random mechanics, they are not random enough (at least for me).The biggest problem being the animatronics attacking from the same spots (Bonnie from the left door, Chica from the right door, Foxy only approaching the left door and freddy from the right. This leads to a fair amount of predictabilitie and using "strategies" which are not exactly fun in my opinion. For instance: you simply have to check the left and right door with the lights and be ready to close the door for chica and bonnie, since they won't "unexpectibly" teleport into your office. This will make the cameras for them pretty much pointless and the camera will be used for someting more simplier and more predictable. This means you will watch a total of only 2 cameras in an entire night, and you won't even look at them for long. The cameras will be used to slow down foxy and Freddy to prevent them from attacking and to check for foxy, when he is ready to attack. Another thing is the lack of "animation" in the game. all (except for Foxy) animatronics simply teleport from room to room, making the cameras to watch their position almost pointless (for chica, bonnie and Freddy) since they can almost instantly teleport near your office and before you find all of them, one will be in your office, ready to attack. If the animatronics would actualy "move" and even attack from random doors then the camera would get a much better mechanic in the game and it is more crucial to watch their positions in order to know when and WHERE they attack. The last thing the game being to short. I didn't complet the game to 100% but i got from night 1 through night 5 (with night 5 completed) in slightly above an hour and I died only once in night 1 because I was unaware of Foxy being active in the first night if you dont watch the camera at all (I was using only the lights since I knew that only Bonnie and maybe chica are active in this night). Since one night is aprox. 8min and 30 secs I would've complete the game in less then 1 and a half hour 100% using the same strategy and I would not have to replay the game again for pure "fun" in gameplay. instead I would or still am speculating about theories then, which is by far more fun espacialy with the 2nd game being out. The last thing being the lac of options. You are not able to set resolutions and adjust the game volume which doesn't nececcary destroy the game, but is rather annoying and woth mentioning.--Conclusion--If the game didn't have these theories and a "deep story" which you have to uncover yourself, then I would probably ignore the game and the game would've been not worth at all with it's to simple mechanics. I know that it was only 1 Developer and that it would've much more difficult to animate every animatronic. But it wouldn't be impossible since Foxy is almost fully animated and the jumpscares itself are animated aswell. The Graphic style is something you can only judge subjectivly, since I don't have anything about the style. If you want to buy the game for pure gameplay, then I would reccomend you to stay away from it since this won't have enough for you to please you.I recommend the game only to those, who want to find out more about the game and be able to speculate better about theories and even start new theories.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												Now THIS is the way that indie games should be made.  It's simple in concept, relatively minimal in execution, but is so cleverly designed that you barely notice how "little" there actually is "to" it.  It also happens to be tense as all buggery...the first few times I was accosted by the animatronic-horrors-run-amok, I literally jumped in my seat and squealed like a little girl, even as I laughed in delight/terror.  The tone, to this effect, is a perfect balance between offbeat humour and pants-wetting hysteria...it's all quite genius, really.  And not overpriced at five measly dollars, either (an unfortunate mistake a lot of indie developers are making at the moment...I mean, I loved Gone Home, but the twenty dollar price tag was stupidly steep).   Scott Cawthon is clearly a very clever man. Verdict: 9.5/10.(PS Have only made it to Night 4 so far.  Nearly got to 6am on ONE occasion.  NEARLY.  Lord, grant me the courage...)

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												When I first played this, it scared the crap outta me. I don't play any horror games that much, but this game is one of the most scariest and terrifing game ever. So many jumpscares though. I think I like this game a lot. This game is about the animatronics named Freddy, Bonnie, Chica, and Foxy attempting to kill you and stuffing you in a suit. So you play as the security guard named Mike Schmidt and your objective is to survive Night 1-5, 6, and 7 from 12 A.M. through 6 A. M.  without wasting powers. Like I said, the game is really scary so you might wanna try it out.Now the question is this: Are you ready for Freddy? Because I'm ready for Freddy.

number of helpful: 12 of 22 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												FNAF 1 is still an okay game but I cannot recommend this to people or horror junkies who are looking for a true survival horror experience. At first, one would think this game has it all. Jump scares. Creepy enemies. Creepy atmosphere. All in one package. But it does not live up to be a true horror experience. The main problems are that the main character only stays in ONE spot and the jump scares are EXTREMELY overused and repetitive which are not what I am looking for in a horror game. I still suggest this game for people (casuals) are who being introduced to the horror genre of gaming and who are interested in playing horror games for the first time though. FNAF is perfect for those kinds of people. Not the horror junkies or people who want to truly experience the survival / psychological horror genre such as System Shock 2, Layers of Fear, Phantasmal, Silent Hill, Dungeon Nightmares II, etc.. And about the FNAF fanbase... Well, let's not go there.5.2 out of 10

content:
Posted: February 24, 2016
												I just don't know what went wrong. After trying so hard to appreciate and even like this game, I found myself having the opposite of fun and wanting some sort of hourly wage just for playing this. People finally managed to talk me into playing this "game," and FNAF not only doesn't compare well to other titles I've been pressured into buying but just doesn't seem to be a game at all. The player has very little actual control and a lot is left up to random chance. Just about the only feedback the game provides the player with is jumpscares. Winning a level doesn't feel rewarding at all.The best way to win this game is by refusing to play. You can then construct the lore of an employee of Freddy Fazbear's Pizza suing the owner for wreckless endangerment after Night One, making millions of dollars in the resulting media fallout and cheesy horror movie series deal. The CIA then swoops in and has the infernal machines cold-rolled and then melted down into a solid cube to be launched into the sun by NASA. The creator of the animitronics is placed on a watch list and told to never create another machine again under threat of assassination. THE END.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												Five Nights at Freddy's is absolutely amazing! It is such a simple, innocent plot for a horror game, yet it is scarier than any other game I have played. it is a 2D game that Scott has done an amazing job making seem 3D by making it seem like the animatronics are moving towards you. Throughout the game you may notice subtle easter eggs that reveal the truly horrifying events that took place at the restaurant, another thing about this game that makes it so great! Even now after having the game for about 2 months, I still jump sometimes. Plus, even after you complete the game, you can still play more to find easter eggs such as Golden Freddy!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												On the surface Five Nights at Freddy's doesn't seem like that scary of a game, and it actually isn't... that is, until you're properly immersed.I've beaten night five, and it was genuinely challenging to manage everything at once.You have a limited amount of power of which you can spend on looking through the cameras, flicking the door lights on/off, and locking the door.  It makes you manage when you look around, and how often you do it.  You can't sit with your eyes glued to the cameras because it'll drain your power just as fast as keeping a door closed.  Speaking of which, I love how all of the devices consume the same power, so there's no inherent punishment for locking down the door, and it just creates a better game flow in my opinion.True fear is created by the feeling of helplessness, and that's something FNaF gets really right.What really makes the game frightening for me is the suspense.  Not of the monsters themselves, I don't find them particularily scary.  What really gets to you is that at any moment you could slip up and blow the game in a second.  You have to keep your guard up the whole time, because at no time during the game are you safe.  The feeling of insecurity, the atmosphere, the apprehension.  Those are what makes the game frightening.Positive.+Great atmosphere / sound effects.+Gameplay makes for intense and frightening moments.+It's not flashy and over the top to ruin the atmosphere.+Challenging enough that you'll get frustrated, but not in an angry 'ragequit' way.+Freddy.  Possibly the scariest animatronic in the game, soley because when he jumps out and frightens me, I'm only half sure he's going to do it, or not expecting it at all.Negative-Graphics.  I'm not expecting it to be a triple A masterpiece, but I'd appreciate the ability to alter the resolution.  It looks crappy on my screen and is a little jarring going from my native of (1680*1050) to the game itself of (1024*768).  It doesn't ruin or detract from the experience in a major way, but it's annoying to me.-Predictable Jump Scares.  Most of the jump scares become predictable really quick, and act more as a 'Dang it I screwed up.' and creates less of a 'pee my pants in fright' reaction.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												Five Nights at Freddy's has a great atmospheric feeling complete with an interesting and unique addition to the horror genre. The gameplay, simple yet creepy visuals and sound design all make it a solid game designed by one man. However after a few nights in the novelty wears off and the atmosphere wears off after multiple replays of the same old jumpscare. The game should've been called 15 Minutes at Freddy's, as it eventually comes across as just a novelty for you and your friends to fool around with on Halloween night. Overall, it's not bad. It just can't really hold up as a playable horror game with it becoming repetitive too soon.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												After watching Markiplier nearly drive himself insane with this game and its sequel (or prequel?) I was inspired to try it for myself. I will be honest, it scares the crap out of me at times and it's nervewracking to play with the lights off, but that isn't enough to make it unenjoyable. Definitely gets the adrenaline going and the uncertainty of how to handle certain characters in the game makes this a very exciting one to play. The price for this and its sequel may be a little steep considering how short the games are, but all in all I don't regret buying it. 4/5 stars and I will be playing the second one once I beat nights 5 & 6.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												Five Nights at Freddy's is a simple game, with a very simple objective: survive the night shift for an entire week. Sound easy? Well, you haven't played it yet.The basic idea is that you are alone in an abandoned restaurant, a la Chuck E. Cheese, where animatronic robot animals power on at night and roam the halls. The only problem, is that if they see you, they think you're an animatronic that isn't inside it's suit. Why is that an issue? Well, because they'll  cram you into a suit, simply mashing your entire body against an array of gears, springs, metal wire, and whatever other horribly painful and deadly things are contained within one. Because, well, the animatronics they want to jam you into aren't exactly "empty suits". Between the strange hallucinations of words appearing on screen from time to time, as well as carnival music, camera malfunctions, limited power that if it runs out you die, and animatronics trying to, essentially, kill you, it's a tense ride if you're willing to get on board.Maybe it's not the scariest game in the world, but try sitting alone in the dark, playing this game with headphones on, and try not to get freaked. It's great fun, and the jump-scares really provide a good amount of amusement, if you want that sort of thing."Not my kind of game", you say. "I don't like horror games; they're boring", you tout. Yeah? Well, you're either a wimp, a 'fraidy cat, or both.Bad excuse :l"I don't have the money".Then don't buy it. What a nice reason that would be :)Oh, and all the whiney people on the internet posting videos and shrieking? Just ignore that; you'll have a great time with this one :)

												At the time of this review FNaFs has already become a trilogy. Should you play the first one? Yes. It has a fresh concept that works really well with it's minimalistic gameplay. The only flaw I see is that, at later/harder levels, the blend of gameplay and tension falls apart as you will most likely have to survive by adopting a quicker pacing to your strategies. Which works well and adds more tention up until you're just clicking everything as fast as you can and you remember that you're playing a game and not just trying to elude Freddy and the gang. But otherwise, it's a great game.
