content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												In realitiy I really hate walking, talking dolls in the first place. When I heard about this game I actually try to advoid it as much as possible. It wasn't until I heard the lore behind the game that really got me to actually get it. Here was I think:Positive: 1. Very Unique, compare to other horror games where you chase or run away from monsters, this you can't which really gives your the feeling of hopeless as they are trying to get you. 2. Even though jumpscares is cheesey, it always gets you all the time even when you expected it. This is the mother load of jumpscares. 3. I have an older brother who always watches scary movies............he won't play this game. Enough said on that. 4. You have to look closely and quickly but there are a few humor in this. For example, there a list of rules somewhere, reading it you'll see a rule that states "Don't poop on floor". I want to hear the story behind that one. 5. Creepy characters: Yes they are not scary, but you have to admit that they are pretty creepy. I'm actually scare of Golden Freddy. *Shivers* Negitive: 1. Loses it's charm: if you play it long enough it starts to lose it's charm. 2. Very repeitive. Yes I haven't played it for a while, but seeing videos and reading "phone guy's" dialog it really creeps me out even to this day. I recomend it to anyone who is looking for something new and something scary.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
												I just recently played this for the first time: 


YouTube™ Video: SECRET CHEAT CODE - Five Nights at Freddy's 

			Views: 1,164,880		

			A secret cheat code has recently been discovered in Five Nights at Freddy's (FNAF) ! Reddit post:...		

I would definately recommend this game to anyone, even the scardey cats like me! Although I am a huge sucker for jump scares, and that's the whole point of this game, I really enjoyed playing it.Here's the breakdown!1. It was easy to understand. There isn't much to tell you what to do, but to be honest the first night kinda plays out like a tutorial. There is still some risk to losing, I assume, but that in itself would be a hard thing to accomplish (unless you left the doors closed and the lights on the whole time). In my opinion even people who don't play games too often would quickly understand that the main objective is not to run out of power!2. It's very immersive. I find that this point is one we often take for granted. How many games can you honestly say you have been completely sucked in to? So much so that you forget that the time is in fact not 2am, and you are not sitting in a creepy office blubbering and praying that the adorably creepy animatronics don't pop to stuff your body into a metal suit, counting the seconds until 6am, or machoing it up and pretending like you don't care that your power is on 1% and it's only just hit 5am!3. The sounds are creepy AF! Having worked on a few mobile games with an indie company I know first hand that sounds play a key role in any game. They can literally make or break a game. This point is also something I think a lot of people take for granted, but I have really got to hand it to the developer here! The ambience is spot on for this game, and I can't decide if I hate that fact or love it.4. It's actually scary. I don't know why, I don't know how, but I was on the edge of my seat while playing this. Sure, I've seen one or two videos on YouTube of people playing this game, but it is NOTHING compared to actually playing it. The difference between watching it and playing it is astounding.For all the positives there are, there isn't much that really brings the game down. Keeping in mind that this is an indie developed game, and there was probably no budget going into it, I can see why it has taken off and developed into a thriving series. The only thing I would do to improve this game is maybe add in a pause menu, or at least change the fact that the esc key completely terminates the game. I accidentally pressed it in an attempt to close the in game monitor before I realised you just hover the mouse over the [VVVVV].

												Five Nights at Freddy's what half of the internet counting me calls the scraiest game in years to come and i gotta say they are right if you want to play a very scray horror game this is the game for you so when you start the first night your in a security office and you get a phone call from the manager after the call you activate your camera and see 3 animatronic animal dolls their names are Freddy Fazbear Chika the Chicken and Bonnie the Bunny and in Pirate Cove in the curtains has Foxy The Pirate Fox and you then noticed that you have only a certain amount of power left you see thats the hard part of this game that and you need to watch the animatronics or close the doors and you can also turn on the lights and check for animatronics and keep watch on foxy or else he will come out of the curtains and start running strait to you so you only have a short second to close the door and after a while he will come back to his curtains and to beat a night you need to get from 12 am to 6 am (7-8 minutes) (4-5 minutes on mobile version) and when you beat all five nights you then see that there is a 6th night and once you beat that you get a custum 7th night which you can adjust the animatronic levels you can either go really east 0-0-0-0 or the incredibly difficult 20-20-20-20 so i recomend this game to ANYONE who wants to play a good horror game.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
												You can't move around, and that adds to the general feeling of helplessness. You can close the two doors you have, look at the cameras, and turn on the door lights. It all takes energy, though. Even doing absolutely nothing takes power, so you have to be careful with how you spend it. You have a caller who tells you a little of what to expect each night, while the animatronics roam through the building. Some characters like Foxy have to be checked on (with the cameras, of course)  occasionally so that they don't move.  Overall, I really enjoyed this game, and would recommend it to anyone looking for a good game to make you absolutely paranoid.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												This will sound like a weird intro to this review but I'm not sure when I actually got this game.  I picked it up in a bundle but it wasn't one of the games I bought the bundle for so it sat unplayed on my computer for at least a month, maybe longer, before I started to hear people talk about it.  The buzz was favorable so I fired it up.  My first impression was not favorable.  The learning curve is steep and you are thrown in without any real tutorial or anything.  I died just short of finishing the first night and was kind of frustrated by the experience.  And frustration is something you will have to get used to if you play this game.  The game is a few things, survival horror, resource management, it's also a puzzle game.  I say it's a puzzle game because there are specific rules the game follows and figuring these rules out requires a lot of trial and error.  Trial and error gameplay seems especially punishing in this game because of the simplistic controls and interface.  FNAF is a masterpiece at building tension and even though it tells you that the jump scares are coming they're effective.  The only game I can remember playing in recent memory that could get me an adrenaline rush that left my hands shaking was Dark Souls and if you venture into the infamous 4/20 mode you'll see that the unforgiving difficulty is very much on par with the worst that Dark Souls had to offer.  This is a quality game and I highly reccomend it if you're looking for a challenge, or even if you don't decide to torture yourself with the bonus modes, a creep diversion.  It's also available on iOS and Android and the iOS port is very good but it is easier.  If you're looking for the real challenge get it here.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												[ Possible Spoilers ]     I've got to say, Freddy Fazbear's Pizza sounds like a failing establishment, which really adds to the atmosphere, making the player think that the animatronics are merely carcases for the deceased children to roam around in, attempting to make everything right by coming to stuff you into a suit. I also love the conservitive addition, having only Scott Cawthon perform the phone guy's voice. You can also say that this game is a step up from the usual horror game as you are a sitting duck, in one room, while in other games, you have to roam around, probably with someone chasing you. The very little issue of repitition does stand, as there are no little minigames, anything else, so when you finish the game, thats all. Out of all, I think the game deserves my following score:+-+-+-+Score+-+-+-+Originality: 19 / 20Style: 20 / 20Story: 15 / 20Compatibility: 20 / 20Control: 20 / 20Total: 94 / 100 - 5 StarsI recommend you buy this game, and also give the second one the kind of praise you would the first one.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												7/10Fun little horror game, recommend.It's more frustrating than scary, though.  Night 5 was the worst for me because Freddy is a serious troll.  I found that if you don't stress yourself out over it, then you do better and I was able to get through the first four nights without dying.  And there's a pattern you can follow to help you out.  Wish the backstory was more in your face and obvious because it's so easy to miss as it is right now.--Pros--- Great atmosphere for a horror game- Love the use of sounds to indicate the locations of the animatronic- I love the graphics, even if they are mostly just pictures- Foxy's little animation is good for catching people off guard--Cons--- Jumpscares get old really fast- Power system runs on dumb logic- Backstory isn't obvious enough- Needs more creepy imagery when you're going insane- Why do we keep coming back?

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												Five Nights at Freddy's is undeniably a popular game. YouTuber's are all posting Let's Plays of them, and the hype of this game spreads far and wide. For five dollars, one must ask, "Why?" I mean, it's a really cheap game from a relatively unknown developer. Why does everyone adore this game?The answer: A refreshing change from the generic modern horror theme. This game offers something that isn't showcased in the majority of top dollar horror games, especially from the developers who have established a series such as Resident Evil and do not wish to deviate from the action theme. In fact, I believe this spin on modern horror is so unique in nature and mechanics that this is the core reason this game is so popular. And for good reason.I'll break it down for you.Imagine the following: You've applied and been accepted for a nightwatchman position at a local pizzeria. The restaurant is famous for its lovable animal robots, namely Freddy Fazbear, Chica, Bonnie, and Foxy. During the day, these animatronics play music for the crowd, and please the kids while they chow on pizza. During the night, things turn for the worse. Said robots are a little stressed out, and they love to walk around to "work out the kinks". And you're charged with keeping an eye on them with the cameras. And they are programmed to stuff any endoskeletons (you) exposed into costumes (death). And they love to stop by outside your door, and you must be aware of where they are, for if you don't catch them outside your doors fast enough, they love to pull a jumpscare on you. And you have limited power to work with; using the cameras, lights, and doors drains your power. And you have to survive 6 hours (game time). And you only get paid $120 for 5 nights. I wouldn't take the job even if it only included the last contention.The unique spin is that you never actually have the power to combat or face your foes. You are a helpless lamb; you must use intelligence and perception to survive the night. This deliberate siphoning of force from your hands is the reason why people are always coming back. And it's the reason why I defintely recommend this game to anyone wanting a refreshing spin on horror games. The only downside I could consider is the one dimensional style of play, but I definitely foresee expansions and mods coming out for this type of game.Oh, and did I mention that it's five bucks? w00t w00t.Overall rating: 4.5/5, would freddy again

content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												I got this game because I though it would help me get settled in into the horror genere. Five Nights At Freddy isnt like and normal horror game, ya' know, walk around some random place, dont get killed by the many creatures that lurk the area, and once you escape, you win. Five Nights At Freddys however, is alot diffrent however. You are stuck in a room with limited power, and once that power runs out, Freddy Fazbear (as I like to call him, Freddy Fagbear), will come to end your long night. This game REALLY builds up tensity, because half the time I press escape (if you didnt know, the button that instantly closes the game), and most of the time I just keep flipping the camera to kinda help slow down the anamatronics in there position. A few flaws though is once you know how to tell an anamatronic is is your room, or one is running to your room, it isnt as scary, but still, it makes me extremely tense. Hope this reveiw helps you decide weather you want to buy the game or not, and I hope you have a nice day :D

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												This is probably the best horror game of the year! This game uses new mechanics combinded with a awesome concept. Never have I seen a game based on animatronics in a pizza parlour. The idea is original and great to build story and lore off of. The end of the game leaves you clueless and makes you wonder what happened in Freddy Fazbear's Pizza before you got your job there. It's surprising that only one man had worked on this as it would have taken alot of time and talent to make such a great game. This game didn't follow in the footsteps of the sterotypical first person horror. The jumpscares were not cheesy and jumpscares were sometimes not even needed to scare the player. Gameplay was always interesting thoughout the whole game as none of the animatronics had a set path making it very scary and intense to not know what they might do next. It was great to add in the feature when you thought you had finished the game on the 5th night you actually hadn't. Also finding some of the hidden lore and easter eggs in this game makes the player more interestered in the story. If you are reading this and you haven't bought this game yet, Immediately scroll upwards and buy this game! For $5 this game is worth it. The community can't wait to see what else this game has to offer when the sequel to this is released. I approve of this game.Keep up the good work Scott Cawthon!

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												In realitiy I really hate walking, talking dolls in the first place. When I heard about this game I actually try to advoid it as much as possible. It wasn't until I heard the lore behind the game that really got me to actually get it. Here was I think:Positive: 1. Very Unique, compare to other horror games where you chase or run away from monsters, this you can't which really gives your the feeling of hopeless as they are trying to get you. 2. Even though jumpscares is cheesey, it always gets you all the time even when you expected it. This is the mother load of jumpscares. 3. I have an older brother who always watches scary movies............he won't play this game. Enough said on that. 4. You have to look closely and quickly but there are a few humor in this. For example, there a list of rules somewhere, reading it you'll see a rule that states "Don't poop on floor". I want to hear the story behind that one. 5. Creepy characters: Yes they are not scary, but you have to admit that they are pretty creepy. I'm actually scare of Golden Freddy. *Shivers* Negitive: 1. Loses it's charm: if you play it long enough it starts to lose it's charm. 2. Very repeitive. Yes I haven't played it for a while, but seeing videos and reading "phone guy's" dialog it really creeps me out even to this day. I recomend it to anyone who is looking for something new and something scary.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
												I just recently played this for the first time: 


YouTube™ Video: FEMALE JUMPSCARE? | Five Nights at Freddy's - Nights 1 & 2 

			Views: 130		

			I really am scared of watching horror movies, so let's see how I go with the most horrific game of 2014! Five Nights at Freddy's, as fun as it is, scares me to the brink of pressing the escape key!		

I would definately recommend this game to anyone, even the scardey cats like me! Although I am a huge sucker for jump scares, and that's the whole point of this game, I really enjoyed playing it.Here's the breakdown!1. It was easy to understand. There isn't much to tell you what to do, but to be honest the first night kinda plays out like a tutorial. There is still some risk to losing, I assume, but that in itself would be a hard thing to accomplish (unless you left the doors closed and the lights on the whole time). In my opinion even people who don't play games too often would quickly understand that the main objective is not to run out of power!2. It's very immersive. I find that this point is one we often take for granted. How many games can you honestly say you have been completely sucked in to? So much so that you forget that the time is in fact not 2am, and you are not sitting in a creepy office blubbering and praying that the adorably creepy animatronics don't pop to stuff your body into a metal suit, counting the seconds until 6am, or machoing it up and pretending like you don't care that your power is on 1% and it's only just hit 5am!3. The sounds are creepy AF! Having worked on a few mobile games with an indie company I know first hand that sounds play a key role in any game. They can literally make or break a game. This point is also something I think a lot of people take for granted, but I have really got to hand it to the developer here! The ambience is spot on for this game, and I can't decide if I hate that fact or love it.4. It's actually scary. I don't know why, I don't know how, but I was on the edge of my seat while playing this. Sure, I've seen one or two videos on YouTube of people playing this game, but it is NOTHING compared to actually playing it. The difference between watching it and playing it is astounding.For all the positives there are, there isn't much that really brings the game down. Keeping in mind that this is an indie developed game, and there was probably no budget going into it, I can see why it has taken off and developed into a thriving series. The only thing I would do to improve this game is maybe add in a pause menu, or at least change the fact that the esc key completely terminates the game. I accidentally pressed it in an attempt to close the in game monitor before I realised you just hover the mouse over the [VVVVV].

content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												The Five Nights at Freddy's series is one of my personal favorites. I don't believe what others tell me. It has a unique story line, along with very different game mechanics. It is a fun challenge to defeat, but I love everything about it. When I found out it was made in Clickteam Fusion 2.5, I got excited. I wanted to figure out HOW Scott Cawthon made the game. Eventually, with research and my own work, I figured out how. But, I still haven't released any of my FNaF fan games as of May 31st, 2015. I recommend this game, even though I haven't spent too much time on PC, I did on my other iPad.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												I never owned a game that I was truly afraid to play...  Not even as a child.  Sure, I had games that were a little disturbing or the imagery was a little graphic or things just sort of popped out at you and made you jump.  But I never had a game I was truly afraid to play.  That is until about an hour ago after I bought this...I'm still going to play it and work my way through all the days and even try again for day 6.  Heck, I even have plans to buy the sequel.  But that's not to say that this game doesn't really scare me.  It's a controlled scare, sort of like riding a really intimidating roller coaster.  However, the scare is in a much different way.  The game plays with you.  It makes you start questioning every little thing that happens or that you think is happening.  It really make you contemplate the next time you wanna play it.  In fact, I want to do another round of this, but instead I chose to write this review since you do need a sort of emotional cool down after getting into this.I highly recommend this game if you're a fan of survival horror...  Or if you just like to be scared and don't want to do something idiotic like walk down dark alleys in downtown.  It's a game that's supposed to make you feel arfaid/paranoid/unnerved and it does a top notch job of it.

												Five Nights at Freddy's what half of the internet counting me calls the scraiest game in years to come and i gotta say they are right if you want to play a very scray horror game this is the game for you so when you start the first night your in a security office and you get a phone call from the manager after the call you activate your camera and see 3 animatronic animal dolls their names are Freddy Fazbear Chika the Chicken and Bonnie the Bunny and in Pirate Cove in the curtains has Foxy The Pirate Fox and you then noticed that you have only a certain amount of power left you see thats the hard part of this game that and you need to watch the animatronics or close the doors and you can also turn on the lights and check for animatronics and keep watch on foxy or else he will come out of the curtains and start running strait to you so you only have a short second to close the door and after a while he will come back to his curtains and to beat a night you need to get from 12 am to 6 am (7-8 minutes) (4-5 minutes on mobile version) and when you beat all five nights you then see that there is a 6th night and once you beat that you get a custum 7th night which you can adjust the animatronic levels you can either go really east 0-0-0-0 or the incredibly difficult 20-20-20-20 so i recomend this game to ANYONE who wants to play a good horror game.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												Well constructed scary atmosphere which draws on your childhood fear of clowns and chuck e cheese, a very basic resource management angle which is somewhat forced into place but does its job, and simple mechanics and setting which do a good job of making you feel helpless while drama unfolds. Many people may be turned off by that helplessness, but for those who dont mind it this is a fun little experience. Made me scream like a little girl.Recommend you buy if you like animated shorts in the horror genre or otherwise dig horror games, and don't mind shelling out 5 beans for something with relatively little replayability.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
												To be entirley honest, as i look at all the sequels that have come out to this game i realize that the franchise is starting to become a little milked, but i still have to give this game credit for what it did.Even if your a fnaf hater even you have to admit that the idea behind this game was brilliant, to take something average that would normally not be seen as scary and making it into something terrifying.  I think that the lack of movement in this game also adds to the experience, because the feeling of helplessness forces you to rely on your cameras which is argueably the games greatest strength. by using these cameras it creates an atmospheric kind of scare rather than cheap jumpscares (which are in this game i should note) but for me what really stood out was the way that this game portrays this childrens pizzeria, and makes it into a place that looks like it could be home to a slasher villian.this game is a little limited in gameplay but its very atmospheric and the animatronics are all memorable and in an odd way have their own unique behaviors.  Although the game has several flaws, such as a stupidly low power meter, and doors that open when the power goes out for some reason, the overall experience comes off as being creative and fresh for the horror genre. p.s. much better than any of the sequels in my opinion

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												Five Nights at Freddy's is...the most terrifying game I have ever played. I can hardly even press the continue button now. The title screen freaks me out as well. On the first night, it wasn't too bad; the animatronics were not active for the duration of the first call of the Phone Guy, which saved me a couple of hours. (The only thing I did during that time was listen to call, get used to where the cameras are located, and getting to know the controls). But on the second night...I didn't even get past 50%/3 AM. Bonnie made me scream. I died horribly. After I returned to title screen, I just quit. The most scary thing about this game is that you are alone, and it is EXTREMELY quiet (Apart from footsteps, banging noises, etc). And you know that you are going to get jumpscared when you LEAST expect it. Do I recommend this game?If you have played many, many horror games, and are used to being jumpscared, then why not? But if you have not played a ton of horror games, and/or have some sort of fear of creepy dolls coming to life, then no. At least not at first. Overall, amazing game, great mechanics, and awesome design. Rating: 10/10Note: See you on the other side...(If you get there)

content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
												Five Nights At Freddy's is a fantastic game! I myself am quite a fan and I love the unique take it has on the survival horror experience. With so many games of the same genre, you have to run and hide, but here there is nothing you can do to escape. And even with a pair of doors, camera system and lights, your power is a concern you must always remember to take into consideration. While the horror quality can degrade after playing it for so long, like I have, the tension is always there to complete every night alive. The most dramatic parts for me are when I am at 5am and my power runs out. I sit still, trying to delay Freddy's attack, hoping and praying to hear the familiar children's cheers as the night ends. Overall, a great game experience, but not for the faint of heart, atleast on the first few attempts. Because no matter how good you think you are, no matter how much you know the multitude of fan theories surrounding the backstory of this game, you are going to die atleast once when playing this unforgettable masterpiece.

												This game is worth the purchase.  Only a couple of minutes into the game and my palms started to sweat with fear.  I have a big fear of mascots/animatronics so this game is probably my worst kind of game but yet, I ADORE it! number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												Do you enjoy being scared? Do you like video games? Do you feel your nightwatch security gaurd should be completely immobile from the waste down? Then Five Nights at Freddy's is a game for you. In Five Nights at Freddy's you are the new nightwatch security gaurd of a haunted Chuck-E-Cheese knock-off. You are a man/woman of few words and you are there to do a job. A job that quite frankly, no one else was desparate enough to do. You will find yourself desparately trying to manage resources as you slam doors in the faces of murderous animatronic animals, and try to survive till your shift ends at 6:00 am. Watch those cameras, don't forget to check those doors, and pray you don't fall short on power. Sit in your office and survive the night or rather 5 of them, here at Freddy's.Pros:+Keeps you on the edge of your seat+Genuinly stressful (But in a good way) once you get into it+The story is hidden, but it's there and it's pretty good+Atmosphere is great and has that feeling of terror that one would experience being helpless, alone, and hunted +Affordable: $5 is less than that grease burger meal at that fast food restraunt you visit way too often to be healthy+Doubles as a minimum wage simulatorCons:-The games concept may have crippled itself in it's simplicity. That being said, it could also be argued that it's what makes the game good. Eh-Quite a few holes in the gameplay that make you say "Why don't you just ..." (sometimes you have to say that's just the way it is. And get past it to enjoy the game)-Sometimes it's just impossible to win. Every once in a while the game will get a wild hare up it's butt and just put you in situations you didn't have the resources to handle in the first place-The game is made of jumpscares.All in all I'd give this game 70/100

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												I never owned a game that I was truly afraid to play...  Not even as a child.  Sure, I had games that were a little disturbing or the imagery was a little graphic or things just sort of popped out at you and made you jump.  But I never had a game I was truly afraid to play.  That is until about an hour ago after I bought this...I'm still going to play it and work my way through all the days and even try again for day 6.  Heck, I even have plans to buy the sequel.  But that's not to say that this game doesn't really scare me.  It's a controlled scare, sort of like riding a really intimidating roller coaster.  However, the scare is in a much different way.  The game plays with you.  It makes you start questioning every little thing that happens or that you think is happening.  It really make you contemplate the next time you wanna play it.  In fact, I want to do another round of this, but instead I chose to write this review since you do need a sort of emotional cool down after getting into this.I highly recommend this game if you're a fan of survival horror...  Or if you just like to be scared and don't want to do something idiotic like walk down dark alleys in downtown.  It's a game that's supposed to make you feel arfaid/paranoid/unnerved and it does a top notch job of it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												Five Night's at Freddy's is a delightful and unique approach to the horror genre. I generally love point and click adventures and use them as a bit of a timewaster. A prime example of this is Pajama Sam: No Need to Hide When It's Dark Outside, a story about a kid who goes into his closet to find the "Land of Darkness" to capture "Darkness" (the main antagonist) and put him in a lunchbox. This is a prime example of a fun and enjoyable point and click adventure. This point and click adventure will have you on the edge of your seat as you try to stop 4 (maybe 5) animatronic creatures murder you in the dead of night at your low paying job. Needless to say, I love this game in the weirdest way possible. And if you don't mind having a few sleepless nights, lash out and pay the $4.99 ($2.49 at the time of writing this review) so the developer can create the sequel that everyone is hoping for to this extremely good game.8.5/10

												Now look, horror games now are pretty popular, but it's all the same, isnt it? Dark and Stormy, noises, your character is breathing so heavy you'd think they ate way too much cake in one sitting. Well, not Five Nights at Freddy's. I've gone all around horror games, from Slender to Amnesia, so I can say that FNaF is something I've never had a chance to really experiance. Now, with most horror games, the goal of the game is to make you feel like you're there, like you're in real danger, and Freddy takes the cake for me. I feel like I'm in the room, checking the cameras, looking at the doors and flipping the lights, but saving power so I don't end up in a costume. This game was so well made, and It's so simple. Please, pick it up, play it, and you'll understand what fear it.Oh, and also, I hate that ♥♥♥♥ing Chicken...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												Yep, I've waited a long time to be able to review this, and now, here it is.I would reccomend this to anyone who wants the spooky/paranoia experience without the blood and gore that you see in stuff like Neverending Nightmares. While blood is acceptable and expected, it isn't something you can have around slightly younger audiences (Not toddlers, but 4th grade through middle school.) However, this game is NOT, I repeat, NOT for everyone.It all depends on how you look at horror games.If you start this game up expecting another Amnesia or Slender type get-chased-by-monster game, then you WILL BE DISAPPOINTED. This game is NOTHING LIKE THEM. In this game, you play as the night guard for a run-down soon-to-close pizzeria with animatronic animals that come to life at night and try to kill you. Think of it as if Chuck E. Cheese and Night at the museum had a baby raised by Satan.In FNaF, you cannot run. No, you aren't running around the Pizzeria trying to not get caught from 12 to 6. You work form a tiny office with 5 ways to interact: Close 2 doors, Turn on 2 lights, and check the various cameras to track Freddy and Co. throughout the building.To sub-quote the mighty BrutalMoose "Essentially you are in the center of a giant Pac-Man maze trying to keep the robots out."This game relies on the creepiness of it's environment as opposed to being scared of Freddy himself. And it does that well. This game changes everything you know about horror games and twists it, and you may or may not love it. It also may or may not be worth the 5 american bucks you spent on it. Fortunately there's a mobile version that's cheaper.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
												There is nothing to fear except fear itself.And Foxy. I forgot about Foxy. You definitely want to fear Foxy.Oh, probably Freddy too. Yeah, he's pretty deserving of your fear.Five Night's at Freddy's is cheap and cheerful scares for the whole family (assuming no-one in the family is of a nervous disposition or suffers from heart problems). It's not going to give you 60 hours of deep, meaningful play, but what it WILL give you is a rather urgent need for new underwear at a price that's probably cheaper than most prescription laxatives.The name of the game here is jumpscares aplenty and enough nervous tension to fill an entire season of American Horror Story. You carefully manage your resources (in this case power) whilst trying to keep a collection of terrifying animatronics from turning you into puree, providing an interesting psychological battle between the player's desire to conserve power for dire situations and the rather more primal need to check the damn cameras every two seconds in order to keep tabs on the ever-advancing enemy. In theory it's easy, in practice? Slightly less so.The biggest drawback would be the low production values (although at £3.99, I'm not sure what people were expecting) - the lack of any graphics/resolution options is a bit galling in today's gaming environment, and if you're nitpicking, gameplay is little more than a cross between a point-and-click game and a slightly more complex version of rock-paper-scissors - once one knows the attack patterns of the bots and the initial terror starts to wear thin, an organised player should have no problem beating the game.At this price though, it's hard to really find fault with a game that does such an effective job at raising the player's pulse whilst also guaranteeing they'll never be able to watch Sesame Street again. If you're a fan of the build-tension-until-jumpscare style of horror, or you just really enjoy falling off your chair and swearing, this is a must-buy.

The controls are so simple but beautifully crafted into the dark and dank atmosphere of "Freddy Fazbear's Pizza"!  Every time, no matter how safe you may be, you never feel safe AT ALL. Five Nights At Freddy isnt like and normal horror game, ya' know, walk around some random place, dont get killed by the many creatures that lurk the area, and once you escape, you win. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												Five Nights at Freddy's is undeniably a popular game. YouTuber's are all posting Let's Plays of them, and the hype of this game spreads far and wide. For five dollars, one must ask, "Why?" I mean, it's a really cheap game from a relatively unknown developer. Why does everyone adore this game?The answer: A refreshing change from the generic modern horror theme. This game offers something that isn't showcased in the majority of top dollar horror games, especially from the developers who have established a series such as Resident Evil and do not wish to deviate from the action theme. In fact, I believe this spin on modern horror is so unique in nature and mechanics that this is the core reason this game is so popular. And for good reason.I'll break it down for you.Imagine the following: You've applied and been accepted for a nightwatchman position at a local pizzeria. The restaurant is famous for its lovable animal robots, namely Freddy Fazbear, Chica, Bonnie, and Foxy. During the day, these animatronics play music for the crowd, and please the kids while they chow on pizza. During the night, things turn for the worse. Said robots are a little stressed out, and they love to walk around to "work out the kinks". And you're charged with keeping an eye on them with the cameras. And they are programmed to stuff any endoskeletons (you) exposed into costumes (death). And they love to stop by outside your door, and you must be aware of where they are, for if you don't catch them outside your doors fast enough, they love to pull a jumpscare on you. And you have limited power to work with; using the cameras, lights, and doors drains your power. And you have to survive 6 hours (game time). And you only get paid $120 for 5 nights. I wouldn't take the job even if it only included the last contention.The unique spin is that you never actually have the power to combat or face your foes. You are a helpless lamb; you must use intelligence and perception to survive the night. This deliberate siphoning of force from your hands is the reason why people are always coming back. And it's the reason why I defintely recommend this game to anyone wanting a refreshing spin on horror games. The only downside I could consider is the one dimensional style of play, but I definitely foresee expansions and mods coming out for this type of game.Oh, and did I mention that it's five bucks? w00t w00t.Overall rating: 4.5/5, would freddy again

												Now look, horror games now are pretty popular, but it's all the same, isnt it? Dark and Stormy, noises, your character is breathing so heavy you'd think they ate way too much cake in one sitting. Well, not Five Nights at Freddy's. I've gone all around horror games, from Slender to Amnesia, so I can say that FNaF is something I've never had a chance to really experiance. Now, with most horror games, the goal of the game is to make you feel like you're there, like you're in real danger, and Freddy takes the cake for me. I feel like I'm in the room, checking the cameras, looking at the doors and flipping the lights, but saving power so I don't end up in a costume. This game was so well made, and It's so simple. What the game is really about is this guy named Mike is the new night guard at an old run-down pizza place. What happens is that you get all these phone messenges from the old night guard but he is never named so fans call him by the name of Phone Guy. What Phone Guy states helps you through the entire game he says that you must conserve power because you have a limited amount. You have cameras to check on the four animatronics ( Freddy, Bonnie, Chica, and Foxy ). The animatronic that you HAVE to check on the most is Foxy who is located in Pirate Cove because if the cameras are on the animals they can't move but Foxy is able to run down the hall into your office. If you close a door it takes away power if you turn on a light it takes power. The animatroinics that are the most active are Bonnie and Chica I love this game you should all try it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												Yep, I've waited a long time to be able to review this, and now, here it is.I would reccomend this to anyone who wants the spooky/paranoia experience without the blood and gore that you see in stuff like Neverending Nightmares. While blood is acceptable and expected, it isn't something you can have around slightly younger audiences (Not toddlers, but 4th grade through middle school.) However, this game is NOT, I repeat, NOT for everyone.It all depends on how you look at horror games.If you start this game up expecting another Amnesia or Slender type get-chased-by-monster game, then you WILL BE DISAPPOINTED. This game is NOTHING LIKE THEM. In this game, you play as the night guard for a run-down soon-to-close pizzeria with animatronic animals that come to life at night and try to kill you. Think of it as if Chuck E. Cheese and Night at the museum had a baby raised by Satan.In FNaF, you cannot run. No, you aren't running around the Pizzeria trying to not get caught from 12 to 6. You work form a tiny office with 5 ways to interact: Close 2 doors, Turn on 2 lights, and check the various cameras to track Freddy and Co. throughout the building.To sub-quote the mighty BrutalMoose "Essentially you are in the center of a giant Pac-Man maze trying to keep the robots out."This game relies on the creepiness of it's environment as opposed to being scared of Freddy himself. And it does that well. This game changes everything you know about horror games and twists it, and you may or may not love it. It also may or may not be worth the 5 american bucks you spent on it. Fortunately there's a mobile version that's cheaper.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												Five Nights at Freddy's; People are calling it the scariest game of the decade, and frankly I kinda' agree. FNaF has a perfect balanced system of suspense and jump-scares to where you can never really expect what's going to happen, which leads me to my next topic; Audio. If you get this game, make sure you have a quiet household and/or headset, because the background sound effects pertain to when someone's moving or not. An example being Freddy's deep disturbing laugh, this indicates that Freddy is no longer on the stage and is coming out for you. Anyway, In conclusion...This game is awesome; great to play with family(scare them to death); Great to play with friends or watch the react to the game-play; and just a cool game to play that's always keeping you on the edge of your seat.RatingsStory: 7/10Gameplay: 9/10Scare Aspect: 9/10Finale: 4/10

												Five Nights at Freddy's is by far the best horror game I've played. It is the very definition of paranoia.You play as a night watch security guard for Freddy FazzBear's Pizzeria (because 4 bucks/hour is pretty cheap). Your job is to watch the security cameras and make sure that the 4 animatronics stay in line. You have control over the security cameras, 2 doors, and lights to see just outside the doors. Using any of those causes your power to drain quicker. You switch on your camera to find that the bots are all where they are supposed to be...Except what if they aren't?In this alternate universe, the bots are set to a 'free roam' setting. They wander around the building on their free will. If they happen to make it to your office, they recognize you as a bot without a costume. They will stuff you in a tiny little suit filled with animatronic gizmos. Nothing to worry about though, you have doors right?In case you forgot doors use power. If you use up all your power, you have to sit there in the dark, and wait for your (very terrifying) death... You literally HAVE to expose yourself to danger in order to survive, which is what bothers most of the people who play it.So was it a $5 well spent? YES YES YES YES!!!!!!!! Obviously yes there are only 5 levels, but you can play those levels over and over. There are so many different scary ways you can die, and every single one fills my pants. Yes 11/10. Done. Finished. Bye

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												Stop. Think about what you are doing."Oh this game isn't scary. Pffft its just a bunch of jumpscares! I can handle it."No. You are wrong, because that is exactly how I felt when I bought this game. I'd watched the trailers and the lets plays. Then I actually tried it from behind the keyboard and I couldn't even do it. Its not wrong to say that this game is mostly jumpscares, and jumpscares are widley regarded as the lowest incarnation at horror. However Five Nights at Freddy's does something different than other horror games. In most horror games the jumpscare is just a one-and-done, a little one trick pony to startle you and which is totally ruined if you see it coming, and ruined even further in the context that in games jumpscares usually don't kill you.In Five Night's at Freddy's, the jumpscare is the lose condition, it is the game over screen. You know the jumpscare is coming, and the game has given you all the tools to prevent the jumpscare. Thats why this game is scary. Its not the jumpscare that gets you, its the anticipation, the stress and the anxiety that gets you. Ben Yahtzee from Zero Punctuation once said that most horror games can be summed up with "A man in a scary mask jumps out and yells 'Aboogiewoogiewoo!' while in a good horror game, the man in the mask is behind you. You know he's going to jump out and yell 'Aboogiewoogiewoo!' but he doesn't he's just stays behind you and lets the fear sink in."Thats this game. This game isn't about the jumpscare at all. Its about the fear you feel when you know the jumpscare is coming and your frantically trying to avoid it.So DON'T buy this game because you think it won't be scary, or because you think you'll impress your friends by showing how brave you are. Buy this game because its scary, because you WANT to be scared.And if this game doesn't manage to freak you out even once, I would love to talk to you personally because I need to know your secret to managing stress and anxiety.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												After watching Markiplier nearly drive himself insane with this game and its sequel (or prequel?) I was inspired to try it for myself. I will be honest, it scares the crap out of me at times and it's nervewracking to play with the lights off, but that isn't enough to make it unenjoyable. Definitely gets the adrenaline going and the uncertainty of how to handle certain characters in the game makes this a very exciting one to play. The price for this and its sequel may be a little steep considering how short the games are, but all in all I don't regret buying it. 4/5 stars and I will be playing the second one once I beat nights 5 & 6.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												What a fantastic and freakin' shocking game!  I LOVED this game.  The developer clearly has a good mind for creating a disturbing and scary environment while writing a very challenging yet believable beatable algorithm.The graphics ARE very basic, but I find that it lends a great deal to the grittier and disturbing feeling of the game.The sound design is exceptionally thought out, despite having a few sfx that seem like they could have a bump in overall quality.The jumpscares are epic, and the overall panic-inducing experience of playing this game is exhilerating.  You'll know what I mean when you first lose track of one of the animatronic characters after seeing all of them standing on the stage for the first half of the night, only to find them grinning at you through the door way a moment later.All this for a surprisingly low price.I look forward to more games by this developer.  DEFINITELY pick this game up wether it's on sale or at the full whopping price of $4.99.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												This is probably the best horror game of the year! This game uses new mechanics combinded with a awesome concept. Never have I seen a game based on animatronics in a pizza parlour. The idea is original and great to build story and lore off of. The end of the game leaves you clueless and makes you wonder what happened in Freddy Fazbear's Pizza before you got your job there. It's surprising that only one man had worked on this as it would have taken alot of time and talent to make such a great game. This game didn't follow in the footsteps of the sterotypical first person horror. The jumpscares were not cheesy and jumpscares were sometimes not even needed to scare the player. Gameplay was always interesting thoughout the whole game as none of the animatronics had a set path making it very scary and intense to not know what they might do next. It was great to add in the feature when you thought you had finished the game on the 5th night you actually hadn't. Also finding some of the hidden lore and easter eggs in this game makes the player more interestered in the story. If you are reading this and you haven't bought this game yet, Immediately scroll upwards and buy this game! For $5 this game is worth it. The community can't wait to see what else this game has to offer when the sequel to this is released. I approve of this game.Keep up the good work Scott Cawthon!

content:

												This is the single worst pizza place I have ever visited.We arrived on a saturday evening for a childs birthday party only to find out that they had lost our reservations.We had to sit in the bar area for allmost 45 minutes for a table to make up for it. The staff didn't even offer us a free drink or anything to make up for THEIR mistake! It wasnt until we FINALLY sat down for our meal that we noticed how run down the place looked. The decor looked very old and dated, The carpet was matted and the place STANK of old. It honestly looked like it hadnt been cleaned since the 1970s. Despite not even getting a "Sorry for you're wait" from the waitress, we were pressured into ordering our food as soon as we sat down. Me and my partner both ordered a Pepperoni while our son got a plain cheese. When the food EVENTUALLY arrived it was awful. The pepperoni may aswell have been called 'plain cheese with a hint of pepperoni' and neither of them had been cooked all the way through. They were more like FROZEN pizzas than resturant quaility pizzas!After finally paying out bill (which we were BLATANTLY overcharged for) we made straight for the exit. But to make matters worse one of the anamatronic animals jumped off the stage, bounded straight for my husband, ripped his skin and flesh off before stuffing his bloodstained skeleton into a furry rabbit suit. Right infront of mine and my sons eyes!B+

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												As with most things that receive so much hype that they're made out to be the holy grail, you may be asking whether Five Nights at Freddy's lives up to that hype. Now I want to make it clear, I do think it's a pretty good game but I don't think it's the masterpiece people make it out to be. People are of course welcome to think it is and it's understandable why, as the game certainly has its fair share of great merits. I will address both the good points and bad points of this game. Keep in mind while reading that I do have an overall positive opinion on FNAF.One of the most important factors of a horror game is obviously whether it's scary. FNAF is scary... to an extent. The atmosphere is most definitely there. The player fills the role of a security guard working the nightshift at a family pizzeria inhabited by animatronic characters. The sounds are largely what make the atmosphere so amazing. From faint tunes apparently coming from attractions within the building, to ambient spooky noises, to even the whirs of the security cameras, the sound design is absolutely excellent in building suspense. The animatronics look terrifying simply standing there on the stage, in the dark, looking a far cry from the delightful entertainers they're supposed to be. One can't help but feel the fear build as they become aware of these characters beginning to skulk the halls, simply roaming, with no programmed objective, thus making them unpredictable.So where does the horror fail? In what it all ultimately builds up to. It's actually something the game points out when it starts up. To me, it's like the game's announcing a major flaw that it doesn't actually see as a flaw. I am of course referring to jumpscares. They're not inherently bad but by god can a work of horror fall back on them too much and FNAF certainly does... not just a little bit, quite a lot. Fortunately I do personally think two of the common jumpscare game overs aren't badly done - these being Foxy's and one of Freddy's (if he catches you before the power goes out.) This is because the animatronics in question look horrifying while doing the attacking. They look nothing like cuddly mascots, only wretched husks of metal and plastic, horribly failed attempts at endearing characters... just as the creator of the game no doubt intended.The other common jumpscare game overs unfortunately don't pull this off in my opinion. The animatronics attacking in those game overs... really do just look like cuddly mascots. It's a delicate art making colourful cartoon animatronics look and seem scary. The game succeeds most of the time but it almost looks like the creator didn't try during those jumpscare screens. Of course jump scaring is a lazy tactic that doesn't require any effort in the first place, so it needs some kind of scary imagery to go along with it. But there is nothing really off about the animatronics during these screens. Arguably Chica looks a little off but I don't feel it.That is the horror of FNAF at its core. Absolutely brilliant build-up, so-so execution due to the far, far too common practice of all horror works - jumpscares. It's just fortunate the game wasn't spoiled altogether by the jumpscares. It's also worth noting, there is a story to the game, both immediately obvious and not so obvious. Those who like to theorise and investigate should like it. That is, if the godawful community doesn't spoil the story for you. I'm also fond of how the game gives you the very brief "pauses" between the horror. The only thing that could possibly be considered something of a break in the horror is the guy who leaves a phone message for you every night. They're short, and in parts creepy in themselves, though usually there's still some lightheartedness to the creepiness. I don't know whether the creator intended for these phone calls to be something for the player to latch to due to there being nothing else to distract from the horror but it certainly works well. Unfortunately if one tries the same night more than once during one game session, the phone call no longer activates, so they have to restart. This is something I'd personally like to see patched.I have a few other issues with the game. First of all, its ending... if it can be considered that. FNAF is in a lot of ways a fairly simple game that one can get a lot out of, so a simple ending works in theory. But for all the effort that one has to put into this frankly very challenging game, the ending kind of feels like a slap in the face. I'd have preferred a bit more, even if it was short. As for the difficulty, I do feel it's somewhat too difficult for a horror game. It ends up making retrying the night feel like routine and the horror starts to fade as a result. Kind of like Slender: The Eight Pages but NOWHERE near as bad. Again, only SOMEWHAT too difficult. Finally, the lack of an option to adjust the screen resolution or any other option for that matter. This is probably why I had to restart my computer to start the game the first time. Why exclude such basic features?So those are my thoughts on FNAF. A pretty good horror experience that could serve to be amazing with a few tweaks here and there. Certainly a thrill to play, however and I would recommend it. It's also quite cheap. If you like horror and generally like what you've heard about this game, there's no reason not to get it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
												Interestingly enough, I have a very...prominant hate for jumpscares, and that may add to why i like this game so much. Let me explain. The whole point of the game is to prevent the (sometimes inevitable, it seems) jumpscare that will end your game. Now, I know that may sound bad, but as long as you keep your wits about you, you really have nothing to worry about. The game is a stress management game, really. the more you use up your resources the more likely you are to be murdered, but at the same time, you cant just sit there and do nothing or you will be murdered eventually anyway. The part of this game i like, is the uneasy feeling you get through the whole thing. I like scary games, but not the "pop out at you" kind. i like the ones that get in your head and mess with you, and this game, to an extent, does. not to mention a few easter eggs here and there. That can never hurt, right?

content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												Five Nights at Freddy's is an Indie, Point-and-click, Survival Horror video game.Although it came out recently, this point-and-click novelty game has a few nasty tricks up their sleeves. In this game, you're a security guard who needs to watch the animatronics during the night shift from 12 to 6 AM. The only problem is that the animatronics tend to wander around after dark... and try to kill you. All you have to do is check the cameras to see where they're at, lighting the hallways to check the blind spots and shut the doors to protect you at all cost, all under a power limit.This video game is quite literally an anxiety manager with it's atmosphere, ambiance and feeling of brutal tension. It is considered a "fantastic example of how cleverness in design and subtlety can be used to make an experience terrifying".It it praised for its unique take on the horror genre. It's also praised for it's minimalistic presentation, especially on the audio and lack of music, for the terror of the game. With the fact that the nervous impulses of the repetitive gameplay that can reach almost OCD-type levels, this tense game is horror done right.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
												Five Nights At Freddy's is a fantastic game! I myself am quite a fan and I love the unique take it has on the survival horror experience. With so many games of the same genre, you have to run and hide, but here there is nothing you can do to escape. And even with a pair of doors, camera system and lights, your power is a concern you must always remember to take into consideration. While the horror quality can degrade after playing it for so long, like I have, the tension is always there to complete every night alive. The most dramatic parts for me are when I am at 5am and my power runs out. I sit still, trying to delay Freddy's attack, hoping and praying to hear the familiar children's cheers as the night ends. Overall, a great game experience, but not for the faint of heart, atleast on the first few attempts. Because no matter how good you think you are, no matter how much you know the multitude of fan theories surrounding the backstory of this game, you are going to die atleast once when playing this unforgettable masterpiece.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												Five Nights at Freddy's is  a one-note joke, a single mechanic, and a single location and manages to take it to a hilarious extreme. Despite the overall lack of depth in gameplay and frustrating difficulty, I still find this game to be a unique experience. It's refreshingly simple and does a good job of breaking free from a lot of the cliche's of modern horror games, especially once you realize that this game does not take itself seriously. At all. The game is simple: you are a security guard at a pizza parlour that includes animatronic animal entertainers. You work the night shift. The animatronic animals like to "roam around" at night. You have a limited amount of power with which to use security cameras to keep track of them, and keep the doors to your office (the only physical location in the game) closed when the animals get too close. If you don't keep track of their movements and they enter, then you're dead. Power tends to run out pretty fast, so the main aspect of the game is that of resource management. It's a simple mechanic, yes, but it will have you frantically switching between the cameras as you lose track of one of the bots, and as panic mounts you'll realize that HE'S RIGHT OUTSIDE THE DOOR! I can see this game being a big hit if played on a big screen at a party or something, considering how fast it plays and how simple it is. As power drains and tension rises it can be hard to focus on conserving power, and when the end comes it is usually hilarious.My main problem with the game is that it's a one-note joke that wears thin after awhile. If you are wanting to play this as a serious game, then move on. It's a gag that will entertain you for 3 hours max, until you let someone else play and don't tell them anything about it. Then you'll get more enjoyment. And probably fewer friends :DFor five dollars, I recommend this game. I think it's a good price for something that's a light-hearted, more competent and slick version of the scary maze game. It tells me that the makers understood what they were doing and didn't want to make the game out to be anything more than it is. And for those of you that think you shouldn't buy it because you've seen a youtube video of it, I'd give the game more credit than that. You don't know what it's like until you're sitting in the security office panning frantically between cameras, hearing them singing ominously in the dark halls of the pizza parlour. YOU DON'T KNOW WHAT IT'S LIKE, MAN!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												Five Nights at Freddy's is by far the best horror game I've played. It is the very definition of paranoia.You play as a night watch security guard for Freddy FazzBear's Pizzeria (because 4 bucks/hour is pretty cheap). Your job is to watch the security cameras and make sure that the 4 animatronics stay in line. You have control over the security cameras, 2 doors, and lights to see just outside the doors. Using any of those causes your power to drain quicker. You switch on your camera to find that the bots are all where they are supposed to be...Except what if they aren't?In this alternate universe, the bots are set to a 'free roam' setting. They wander around the building on their free will. If they happen to make it to your office, they recognize you as a bot without a costume. They will stuff you in a tiny little suit filled with animatronic gizmos. Nothing to worry about though, you have doors right?In case you forgot doors use power. If you use up all your power, you have to sit there in the dark, and wait for your (very terrifying) death... You literally HAVE to expose yourself to danger in order to survive, which is what bothers most of the people who play it.So was it a $5 well spent? YES YES YES YES!!!!!!!! Obviously yes there are only 5 levels, but you can play those levels over and over. There are so many different scary ways you can die, and every single one fills my pants. Yes 11/10. Done. Finished. Bye

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												[ Possible Spoilers ]     I've got to say, Freddy Fazbear's Pizza sounds like a failing establishment, which really adds to the atmosphere, making the player think that the animatronics are merely carcases for the deceased children to roam around in, attempting to make everything right by coming to stuff you into a suit. I also love the conservitive addition, having only Scott Cawthon perform the phone guy's voice. You can also say that this game is a step up from the usual horror game as you are a sitting duck, in one room, while in other games, you have to roam around, probably with someone chasing you. The very little issue of repitition does stand, as there are no little minigames, anything else, so when you finish the game, thats all. Out of all, I think the game deserves my following score:+-+-+-+Score+-+-+-+Originality: 19 / 20Style: 20 / 20Story: 15 / 20Compatibility: 20 / 20Control: 20 / 20Total: 94 / 100 - 5 StarsI recommend you buy this game, and also give the second one the kind of praise you would the first one.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												This will sound like a weird intro to this review but I'm not sure when I actually got this game.  I picked it up in a bundle but it wasn't one of the games I bought the bundle for so it sat unplayed on my computer for at least a month, maybe longer, before I started to hear people talk about it.  The buzz was favorable so I fired it up.  My first impression was not favorable.  The learning curve is steep and you are thrown in without any real tutorial or anything.  I died just short of finishing the first night and was kind of frustrated by the experience.  And frustration is something you will have to get used to if you play this game.  The game is a few things, survival horror, resource management, it's also a puzzle game.  I say it's a puzzle game because there are specific rules the game follows and figuring these rules out requires a lot of trial and error.  Trial and error gameplay seems especially punishing in this game because of the simplistic controls and interface.  FNAF is a masterpiece at building tension and even though it tells you that the jump scares are coming they're effective.  The only game I can remember playing in recent memory that could get me an adrenaline rush that left my hands shaking was Dark Souls and if you venture into the infamous 4/20 mode you'll see that the unforgiving difficulty is very much on par with the worst that Dark Souls had to offer.  This is a quality game and I highly reccomend it if you're looking for a challenge, or even if you don't decide to torture yourself with the bonus modes, a creep diversion.  It's also available on iOS and Android and the iOS port is very good but it is easier.  If you're looking for the real challenge get it here.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												I know this game has been reviewed a bunch, but I'd like to share my take on ol' Freddy and his crew. I've played a good number of scary games, but none have made me feel as helpless and paranoid as Five Nights at Freddys. When you start playing and watch the animitronics move around, it's one of the most intense experiences you can go through. Just sitting there, unable to move, and the fear of a robot animal sneaking in at any second to kill you, the fear filling yu with each second. Every time you look at the time, it feels like your chances of survival slip every more quickly as you realize it hasn't even been an hour since you last checked that clock. No other game has made me feel like turning on all my lights and huddling in a corner like this one. Now, this doesn't make it perfect. One of the big flaws for this game is the repetitive atmosphere. If you sit there for a few hours and play this, the fear just dies, because you figure out when your threatened and when you need to use that valuable power. And the big rule in horror games is that when you lose the atmosphere, you lose the player. With this in mind, I still enjoyed this game. If you want to capture what it's like to be near helpless while a bunch of murderous robots are stalking you, buy this game!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												What happened to the horror genre? Did it die? Was it replaced with mindless mass appeal action with a horror theme yet no actual fear factor? Yes... and no. The horror genre has been placed in the hands of indie developers and in those hands it still thrives with games like this. The indie gaming industry proves it can continue to add new ideas to the genre while still providing that heart-attack inducing fear we felt the first time we played Silent Hill, Resident Evil or Eternal Darkness. Amnesia showed us first person games don't always need guns and weapons, it also proved that if you've already evacuated your bowels while playing the next scare will bring out unprocessed food.Five Nights at Freddy's shows us that heart attacks are can happen to people of any age.... okay all jokes aside this game really does stand out in the horror genre. You don't actually do anything, you aren't walking around or looking for clues. No instead you just sit there... knowing something will happen and you don't know when it will come or what will come at you but you know. It's a feeling of dread and fear that I... honestly havent experienced in a horror game before. Something about these ungodly abominations just toying with you, gives you the sense of helplessness as if you're at the mercy of these things. Usually these types of indie games don't appeal to me. Like all those knock versions of Slenderman.... actually I didn't even like Slenderman. But this, this is not some indie horror game from the quick and easy production line up of such games like Spongebob Slendypants... no this is a stand out title. Almost like a point and click adventure but without the adventure. The person/people who made this game knew what scared people and they utilized that with game mechanics that require you to think clearly and react to what you see and hear. Which is extremely hard to do when your having a bowel evacuating heart-attack. Nonetheless I love this game and it's something I hope to see more of.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												Five Nights at Freddy's is by far the best horror game I've played. It is the very definition of paranoia.You play as a night watch security guard for Freddy FazzBear's Pizzeria (because 4 bucks/hour is pretty cheap). Your job is to watch the security cameras and make sure that the 4 animatronics stay in line. You have control over the security cameras, 2 doors, and lights to see just outside the doors. Using any of those causes your power to drain quicker. You switch on your camera to find that the bots are all where they are supposed to be...Except what if they aren't?In this alternate universe, the bots are set to a 'free roam' setting. They wander around the building on their free will. If they happen to make it to your office, they recognize you as a bot without a costume. They will stuff you in a tiny little suit filled with animatronic gizmos. Nothing to worry about though, you have doors right?In case you forgot doors use power. If you use up all your power, you have to sit there in the dark, and wait for your (very terrifying) death... You literally HAVE to expose yourself to danger in order to survive, which is what bothers most of the people who play it.So was it a $5 well spent? YES YES YES YES!!!!!!!! Obviously yes there are only 5 levels, but you can play those levels over and over. There are so many different scary ways you can die, and every single one fills my pants. Yes 11/10. Done. Finished. Bye

content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												I got this game because I though it would help me get settled in into the horror genere. Five Nights At Freddy isnt like and normal horror game, ya' know, walk around some random place, dont get killed by the many creatures that lurk the area, and once you escape, you win. Five Nights At Freddys however, is alot diffrent however. You are stuck in a room with limited power, and once that power runs out, Freddy Fazbear (as I like to call him, Freddy Fagbear), will come to end your long night. This game REALLY builds up tensity, because half the time I press escape (if you didnt know, the button that instantly closes the game), and most of the time I just keep flipping the camera to kinda help slow down the anamatronics in there position. A few flaws though is once you know how to tell an anamatronic is is your room, or one is running to your room, it isnt as scary, but still, it makes me extremely tense. Hope this reveiw helps you decide weather you want to buy the game or not, and I hope you have a nice day :D

content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												I had been wanting to play this game for a long time. I watched a few YouTube gamers play it, such as Markiplier and PewDiePie, so I had a pretty good idea of how the game's mechanics worked. This did little to lessen the impact of the game. It is still the most frightening game I have ever played.Do not let the incredibly simple mechanics fool you. Five Nights at Freddy's is surprisingly challenging. The power supply is stingy and the anamatronics can be very persistent in catching you. It gets a little old if you play it for too long at a time, but it is a fabulous game!

Posted: July 26, 2015
												This game is much different from other horror games out there. Not being able to move and looking at these 'lifeless' dolls really creeps me out. The controls are easy and are explained through phone guy who really sets up tention between you an the game. The grafics are kind of bad but no game is 'perfect'. The one thing alot of people hate about this game is that the jump scares suck. I will admit that they really can only get you acouple times but that doesn't ruin the game. This is a game that once you start you have to finish.Pros:Great atmisphere Lots of easter eggsGood story easy controlsCons:Jump scared can really only get you one timeThe community is terrible. So many haters to the point that you make a joke they all jump at the chance to say something negative to you.  Another thing i want to cover that i hear alot of people blab about is that this franchise is just slender woods (Idk what the game is called) but with animatronics. Not true. In that game you move and the tention comes from being able to see him staring at you all the time. With fnaf its a little like that but the sounds play a bigger role in it. All in all its really fun and i am currently on night 5. I suggest getting it.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												I have a love/hate relationship with Five Nights at Freddy's. I orginally thought that this would be a fun little time sink styel of game; a couple of jump scares, some jokes about greasy pizza and a game over screen, not something that would friggin' haunt me. Granted, it doesn't have sparkling graphics, but FNaF proved that you don't need it to make something genuinely spooky. On the downside, I now get a little unconscious jolt of panic whenever I see a draining battery symbol. On the upside, I no longer need to go to the bathroom.Just for the record, Scott, you owe me a new pair of pants.As the restaurant's (apparently suicidal, from how many times you go back) night guard, it's the player's job to keep a close eye on the animatronics after dark and keep things under wraps for the company. However, with the dark corners and blind spots perfect for a mischevious bunny coupled with energy resource management, this quickly went from a slightly eerie quick game to play to a legitimately unsettling and really freakin' tense experience, made all the more nerve wracking by the 'crew' and their tendency to violently invade your personal space at a bowel-evacuatingly frequent pace. Probably my best (worst?) and first experience with Bonnie resulted in a couple of broken computer accessories and very sore kneecaps. Seriously, the rabbit might not appear all that from a distance, but that's no ordinary rabbit. Just look at the bones, he's got a vicious streak a mile wide.All in all, I definitely don't regret buying this game, nor do I regret playing it.I do, however, regret not being ready for Freddy.Definitely worth a play or fifty, whether you're prepared or not.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
												To be entirley honest, as i look at all the sequels that have come out to this game i realize that the franchise is starting to become a little milked, but i still have to give this game credit for what it did.Even if your a fnaf hater even you have to admit that the idea behind this game was brilliant, to take something average that would normally not be seen as scary and making it into something terrifying.  I think that the lack of movement in this game also adds to the experience, because the feeling of helplessness forces you to rely on your cameras which is argueably the games greatest strength. by using these cameras it creates an atmospheric kind of scare rather than cheap jumpscares (which are in this game i should note) but for me what really stood out was the way that this game portrays this childrens pizzeria, and makes it into a place that looks like it could be home to a slasher villian.this game is a little limited in gameplay but its very atmospheric and the animatronics are all memorable and in an odd way have their own unique behaviors.  Although the game has several flaws, such as a stupidly low power meter, and doors that open when the power goes out for some reason, the overall experience comes off as being creative and fresh for the horror genre. p.s. much better than any of the sequels in my opinion

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												Five Nights at Freddy's is...the most terrifying game I have ever played. I can hardly even press the continue button now. The title screen freaks me out as well. On the first night, it wasn't too bad; the animatronics were not active for the duration of the first call of the Phone Guy, which saved me a couple of hours. (The only thing I did during that time was listen to call, get used to where the cameras are located, and getting to know the controls). But on the second night...I didn't even get past 50%/3 AM. Bonnie made me scream. I died horribly. After I returned to title screen, I just quit. The most scary thing about this game is that you are alone, and it is EXTREMELY quiet (Apart from footsteps, banging noises, etc). And you know that you are going to get jumpscared when you LEAST expect it. Do I recommend this game?If you have played many, many horror games, and are used to being jumpscared, then why not? But if you have not played a ton of horror games, and/or have some sort of fear of creepy dolls coming to life, then no. At least not at first. Overall, amazing game, great mechanics, and awesome design. Rating: 10/10Note: See you on the other side...(If you get there)
